articles.title: BBC could soon make programmes for release first on YouTube under deal
articles.trailText: Plan follows pressure on broadcaster to put more content on platform, but raises questions about licence fee
articles.summary: The BBC is considering making programmes debut on YouTube to reach younger viewers after pressure from Ofcom and politicians. Under proposals due soon, shows premiering on YouTube could later appear on iPlayer and Sounds, potentially generating ad revenue outside the UK. The move raises questions about using licence-fee funding for content on a commercial platform and the BBC’s public service remit. Industry expert Stephen Price warned this shift underlines rapid media change enabled by smart TVs and questioned the licence fee’s purpose. Data show YouTube’s UK reach now exceeds the BBC’s for short viewing, though BBC leads on longer sessions.

articles.title: CBS News report on ICE officer’s injuries drew ‘huge internal concern’
articles.trailText: Anonymously sourced report that Jonathan Ross ‘suffered internal bleeding’ after killing Renee Good faced skepticism inside CBS newsroom
articles.summary: Internal CBS News emails reveal ‘huge internal concern’ after two anonymous US officials were cited in tweets and a story claiming ICE officer Jonathan Ross suffered torso internal bleeding after fatally shooting Renee Good in Minneapolis. Staffers flagged broad sourcing, questioned medical details—from surgery to bruises—and worried the report echoed Trump administration messaging. Top editor Bari Weiss pressed coverage amid dissension. ABC, NBC, NYT and Fox News echoed the claim; Guardian hasn’t confirmed. CBS defended its editorial rigor; critics cite potential bias under new Paramount Skydance ownership.

articles.title: More than 100,000 people urge MPs to ban social media for under-16s in UK
articles.trailText: Letters sent using campaign group’s template as Keir Starmer indicates Australia-style move being considered
articles.summary: Over 100,000 constituents have inundated MPs after Smartphone Free Childhood’s campaign petitioned for an Australia-style ban on under-16s’ social media usage, urging ‘age-appropriate boundaries’. PM Keir Starmer, once skeptical, said he’s watching Australia and that ‘all options are on the table’ to protect under-16s from screen harm. Health Sec Wes Streeting enlisted author Jonathan Haidt to advise on online risks. Australia removed 4.7m under-16 accounts in first days. A Lords amendment may prohibit under-16s’ platform access, forcing a Commons vote. Education unions back a ban, while youth charities warn against blanket prohibitions; government says no ban yet but keeps measures under review.

articles.title: Amol Rajan to leave Radio 4’s Today programme to start own company
articles.trailText: Presenter wants to ‘unleash my inner entrepreneur’ in creator economy but will still host University Challenge
articles.summary: BBC Radio 4 Today presenter Amol Rajan will leave the flagship morning programme to found his own creator-economy company, while continuing to host University Challenge and his Radical podcast. Citing a desire to “unleash my inner entrepreneur,” Rajan joins peers like Piers Morgan in targeting YouTube and TikTok audiences. His departure, following Mishal Husain’s exit, leaves another high-profile vacancy on Today, whose weekly audience, though down from 7m in 2020, remains above 5m. BBC’s John McAndrew thanked Rajan, emphasising plans to refresh the show’s lineup amid digital shifts and Gen Z engagement strategies.

articles.title: Social media time does not increase teenagers’ mental health problems – study
articles.trailText: Research finds no evidence heavier social media use or more gaming increases symptoms of anxiety or depression
articles.summary: A University of Manchester study tracked 25,000 UK pupils aged 11–14 over three years to test if weekday social media (TikTok, Instagram, Snapchat) or gaming time predicted next-year anxiety or depression. Results showed no increase in mental health symptoms for heavier users, whether boys or girls, nor differences between active chatting and passive scrolling. Researchers emphasize screen time alone isn’t harmful but that online experiences, peer interactions and support networks drive wellbeing more than hours logged.

articles.title: Wes Streeting asks US expert Jonathan Haidt to address officials on social media ban for under-16s
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Health secretary issues invitation in push for UK to consider copying landmark restrictions in Australia
articles.summary: Health secretary Wes Streeting has invited US psychologist Jonathan Haidt to advise officials on a potential UK ban on social media for under-16s, mirroring Australia’s new law. Prime Minister Keir Starmer said he will consider stricter youth social-media limits and banning phones in schools, reversing earlier concerns about enforcement and dark-web risks. Cross-party support has grown—Labour, Lib Dems and Reform UK leaders have flagged similar bans—while some ministers and charities worry about policing and unintended consequences. An amendment to the children’s wellbeing bill may enshrine an under-16s ban.

articles.title: Maker of Peaky Blinders ‘in advanced talks’ to merge with The Traitors producer
articles.trailText: Merger between Paris-based Banijay Group and RedBird IMI-owned All3Media would create a European TV production giant
articles.summary: Banijay Group, Europe’s largest independent TV production house behind Peaky Blinders and Big Brother, is in advanced talks with RedBird IMI-owned All3Media (makers of The Traitors, Midsomer Murders, Call the Midwife). The deal would merge hits like MasterChef, Survivor, Race Across the World with Fleabag, Shameless and Squid Game: The Challenge, creating a continental powerhouse. No final decision made; All3Media may inject funds. Any merger would face UK and EU competition scrutiny. Banijay’s past deals include 2019’s $2.2bn Endemol Shine acquisition.

articles.title: BBC seeks dismissal of $10bn Trump lawsuit over Panorama ‘fight like hell’ clip
articles.trailText: Broadcaster’s submission calls on Florida court to throw out defamation case where US president is suing over editing of 6 January 2021 speech
articles.summary: BBC has asked a Florida court to dismiss Donald Trump’s $10bn defamation suit over an edited Panorama clip of his Jan 6, 2021 speech, arguing it lacks personal jurisdiction and improper venue, and that the program wasn’t broadcast or available on BritBox or BBC’s US platforms. The motion also contends Trump failed to plead actual malice and seeks a stay of discovery to avoid extensive probes of its Trump coverage. Trump demands $5bn per count under defamation and Florida’s Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act, with a 2027 trial suggested. The dispute follows BBC apologies and resignations over the edit.

articles.title: David Letterman calls CBS News a ‘wreck’ under newly installed leadership
articles.trailText: Former late-night host makes comments amid merger of CBS’s parent company Paramount with Skydance Media
articles.summary: David Letterman, 78, tore into CBS News as a “wreck” under its new leadership, lamenting how its journalistic integrity—dating back to Edward R. Murrow—has been “trampled on” amid sweeping changes. His critique comes amid Paramount’s merger with Skydance, a $16 million Trump interview settlement, Stephen Colbert’s show cancellation, and Bari Weiss’s chaotic tenure as editor-in-chief, marked by shelving a 60 Minutes prison probe, weak town-hall ratings, anchor shake-ups and staff upheavals. Letterman also praises peers Jimmy Kimmel’s defiance of Disney, Seth Meyers’s work and decries the dwindling late-night political voices.

articles.title: Publishers fear AI search summaries and chatbots mean ‘end of traffic era’
articles.trailText: Media bosses expect web referrals to plunge and want journalists to emulate content creators, report finds
articles.summary: Reuters Institute survey of 280 media leaders in 51 countries finds executives expect AI summaries and chatbots to slash search referrals by 43% over three years (already down 33% in one year), with lifestyle, celebrity and travel sites hit hardest and current affairs more insulated. Google’s AI Overviews top 10% of US results, while ChatGPT referrals remain negligible. Publishers are pivoting to subscriptions, and 75% aim to train journalists as short-form video creators, with 50% planning creator partnerships.

articles.title: Pressure grows on No 10 as Burnham backs Tory call for under-16s social media ban
articles.trailText: Labour Greater Manchester mayor says he agrees with Kemi Badenoch about need to protect young people
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch, Tory shadow minister, proposes banning under-16s from platforms like Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and X to curb addiction and mental-health harm, advocating Australia-style age limits. Cross-party backers include Labour’s Andy Burnham, peers proposing Lords amendments to the children’s wellbeing and schools bill, teaching unions NASUWT and NEU, and health secretary Wes Streeting. PM Keir Starmer and tech secretary Liz Kendall oppose a blanket ban. Government cites its Online Safety Act protecting under-18s while monitoring overseas models and consulting parents and industry. It also enforces rules against harmful content like self-harm and suicide.

articles.title: Ban social media for under-16s, top teaching union urges UK government
articles.trailText: NASUWT says evidence growing that unregulated access affects behaviour in school and harms mental health
articles.summary: NASUWT, one of the UK’s largest teaching unions, has called for a statutory ban on social media for under-16s, warning that unregulated access worsens pupil behaviour, anxiety and mental health. Its survey of 5,800 teachers found 81% noticed rising violent or abusive conduct and 59% identified social media as a key driver; 89% of 300 polled members backed a formal ban. General secretary Matt Wrack argued platforms exploit children’s vulnerabilities and only act under legal compulsion. The appeal follows Australia’s new under-16s ban and concerns over AI tools exposing minors. The government says existing Online Safety Act protections and school phone rules strike the right balance.

articles.title: Inside Tony Dokoupil’s chaotic first week as the CBS Evening News anchor
articles.trailText: The revamped US broadcast has endured a rough start with changed plans, big interviews, social media criticism and an abrupt firing
articles.summary: Tony Dokoupil’s first week as CBS Evening News anchor saw an ambitious “10 cities in 10 days” tour go awry—rerouting from Denver to Minnesota after a deadly ICE shooting—mixed reviews for booking high-profile guests like María Corina Machado, Tom Homan and Pete Hegseth, social media backlash for soft questioning and on-air gaffes, the abrupt firing of top producer Javier Guzman, and a modest ratings bump (4.4m vs. 8.1m on ABC).

articles.title: Tim Davie says BBC will stay on X to try to stem ‘flood’ of global misinformation
articles.trailText: Director general says BBC needs to reach young audiences online amid pressure to leave Elon Musk-owned site
articles.summary: BBC director general Tim Davie announced he will keep the corporation’s presence on Elon Musk’s platform X to counter a surge of global misinformation, despite calls to withdraw amid shifts to the right under new ownership and abuses such as AI-generated sexualized images of minors. Appearing before MPs, he argued access to young audiences is critical to offset state-backed disinformation from China, Iran and Russia. His stance contrasts with former transport secretary Louise Haigh’s exit and Keir Starmer’s demands for regulatory action. The BBC seeks additional World Service funding to sustain efforts in the “space between peace and war.”

articles.title: Huw Edwards’s downfall to be dramatised in two-part Channel 5 series
articles.trailText: Martin Clunes will play former BBC anchor in drama that depicts Edwards’s alleged grooming of a teenager
articles.summary: Channel 5 has commissioned a two-part dramatisation starring Martin Clunes as former BBC news anchor Huw Edwards, charting his 2024 downfall and suspended sentence for accessing indecent images of children as young as seven. The series reconstructs Edwards’s alleged grooming of a vulnerable 17-year-old, drawing on The Sun’s investigation into illicit payments, and traces his BBC career from his 1984 debut to his 2022 royal announcement. Channel 5 chief Ben Frow calls it “important and shocking,” while critic Scott Bryan predicts controversy will drive viewership.

articles.title: Bill Hagerty obituary
articles.trailText: Fleet Street editor and defender of press freedom who worked on Alastair Campbell’s diaries
articles.summary: Bill Hagerty, born in Ilford in 1939, died aged 86 after a 70-year career tracing print’s shift to digital. Starting as a teenage football reporter, he joined the Daily Mirror in 1967 and rose through Mirror Group: deputy editor of the Sunday Mirror (1988–90) and Daily Mirror (1990–91), editor of People (1991–92), and Sunday Today (1987). A staunch defender of press freedom, he chaired the British Journalism Review board (2012–19) and Journalists’ Charity council (2011–12). Author of Read All About It and editor of Alastair Campbell’s Diaries (2010–21), his final column covered Brentford FC. He championed ethics, young‐journalist training and upheld high standards amid industry change.

articles.title: ‘Blood in the water’: Bari Weiss’s chaotic first three months in charge of CBS News
articles.trailText: Weiss is embroiled in her first major controversy as editor in chief as her handpicked anchor takes evening news show
articles.summary: After taking the helm at CBS News without prior television experience, Bari Weiss has spent her first three months amid deep staff skepticism and a faltering business model. Her abrupt decision to pull a Sharyn Alfonsi 60 Minutes segment on El Salvador prison abuses sparked internal uproar and a draft letter—signed by nearly 200 veterans—warning of editorial interference threatening the franchise’s credibility. She’s drawn criticism from both liberal employees and conservative figures like Megyn Kelly and Tucker Carlson, faced cultural clashes over transgender coverage, and unveiled a revamped evening show with Tony Dokoupil. While delivered scoops persist, Weiss’s strategy remains opaque even as owner David Ellison maintains support.

articles.title: Ban on TV junk food advertising before 9pm comes into force in UK
articles.trailText: Watchdog will also monitor online ban for high fat and sugar products as part of wider effort to tackle childhood obesity
articles.summary: On Jan 5 2026 the UK implements a ban on TV junk-food ads before 9 pm and an all-times online ban, enforced by the ASA, covering 13 high-fat, sugar and salt product categories. The rules—voluntarily followed since October—sparked the first low-fat, sugar-and-salt Christmas campaigns and block many ‘reformulated’ snacks plus ostensibly healthy items like sandwiches and porridge. Critics warn brand-only ads (e.g., Cadbury’s drumming gorilla) will dilute impact and highlight a 28% surge in outdoor junk-food spend since 2021.

articles.title: Tom Tickell obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Personal finance editor at the Guardian in the 1970s
articles.summary: Tom Tickell, Guardian’s personal finance editor from 1970–82, died aged 82 after a varied journalism career at the Mail on Sunday, Sunday Telegraph and as a freelance until 2004. Born in wartime Oxford to authors Jerrard Tickell and Renee Haynes, he survived childhood meningitis and studied history at Westminster and Pembroke College, Oxford. A comedian and raconteur, he addressed politics and llamas at Speakers’ Corner, published quizzes, quotes and curiosities, and served as Mental Health Act Commissioner, tribunal member and Pentonville prison visitor. Married to Anne Tomlins in 1979, he had three children, four grandchildren and ten nieces and nephews.

articles.title: Belgian PM’s cat Maximus is social media star with ‘subliminal political message’
articles.trailText: Maximus Textoris Pulcher, an official resident at Rue de la Loi 16, shows a warmer side of Bart De Wever
articles.summary: Belgian PM Bart De Wever’s rescue Scottish fold cat Maximus Textoris Pulcher, an official resident at Rue de la Loi 16, has become Belgium’s second-most followed political Instagram account—only trailing its owner—with 142,000+ followers. Named with mock-grandiose Latin reflecting De Wever’s love of Roman history, Maximus’s low-effort team posts—of him stretching, lolling or sporting thought bubbles about strikes, budget talks or cabinet meetings—serve as a subliminal political tool. Analysts say this “cute cat” tradition humanises the first Flemish nationalist PM, showcasing his hardworking image and warmer side behind the scenes.

articles.title: Trump cuts have fueled ‘rage-giving’ to US rural public radio. Will it be enough?
articles.trailText: Across the US, federal public media cuts have galvanized many communities to donate to their local radio stations
articles.summary: After Trump administration cut CPB funding last July, WYSO in Ohio triggered an emergency drive to plug a $600k hole, spurring record single-day donations and a wave of “rage-giving.” Nationwide, 120k new donors contributed $20m, boosting overall donations by $70m year-over-year and doubling the share of under-45 and online donors. Stations from KSUT to Prairie Public report unprecedented support, while philanthropic commitments of $36.5m and NPR’s $8m relief fall short of the $535m cut. Observers warn the surge may fade once the crisis recedes, leaving rural outlets at risk.

articles.title: ‘Social listening’: Unilever seeks to capitalise on Vaseline’s TikTok moment
articles.trailText: Multinational boosts online chatter after social media users showcase product’s widespread use in life hacks
articles.summary: Unilever is harnessing a TikTok-driven life-hack craze for its 150-year-old Vaseline brand to pivot ad spending from TV and print to social media “social listening”. Viral user videos touted uses—from prolonging perfume and easing spicy-lip pain to household hacks—which Unilever’s scientists validated while debunking myths like teeth whitening. CEO Fernando Fernández and digital head Selina Sykes plan to allocate half its ad budget to content creators, scaling authentic advocacy over broadcast. This shift reflects broader trends: creator-focused ad spend is growing four times faster than traditional media as younger audiences trust influencers. Unilever still values TV’s reach for the Super Bowl.

articles.title: A captive audience for the king’s speech | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Christmas Day TV | Merlin bird app | Pamela Stephenson Connolly | Spirit of disco | Official dogging site | New Invention
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Dec 31 Brief Letters notes that King Charles’s annual Christmas Day message, simulcast across all major channels including GB News, drew nearly 7 million UK viewers. Correspondents also share tech mishaps—Merlin bird app mistaking peacocks for ospreys and ambulance sirens for peregrines—plus a reader whose husband only consents to sex when her letter is published. Other submissions recount local wit: Plymouth’s “Spirit of Discovery” losing its “very,” a hoax “Official dogging site” sign on the Cotswold Way, Shropshire’s New Invention tagged “Patent pending,” and an open invitation for more letters.

articles.title: Ofcom urged to investigate GB News Trump interview over inaccuracy claims
articles.trailText: US president’s assertions climate change is ‘a hoax’ and London has police no-go areas left unchallenged, say critics
articles.summary: Ofcom is under pressure to investigate a GB News November ‘world exclusive’ with Donald Trump after tens of thousands signed complaints alleging the broadcaster failed to challenge dozens of misleading claims. Trump dismissed human-induced climate change as a 'hoax', alleged London has policing no-go zones and enforced 'sharia law', and overstated immigration, law-and-order and energy assertions. Critics including ex-Ofcom standards director Chris Banatvala, LSE climate expert Bob Ward and 38 Degrees say host Bev Turner endorsed or failed to dispute falsehoods, breaching rules on due impartiality and material accuracy. Ofcom is assessing but has not yet launched a formal probe.

articles.title: Claudia Winkleman to host new BBC chatshow
articles.trailText: Strictly and Traitors presenter and ‘true national treasure’ will front The Claudia Winkleman Show from spring
articles.summary: Following her reign on Celebrity Traitors (11 m live viewers) and long stint on Strictly Come Dancing, BBC star Claudia Winkleman will host The Claudia Winkleman Show in spring 2025. Backed by So Television, the network aims to secure high-profile guests and deter rival bids. Winkleman, dubbed a “true national treasure,” calls it an “amazing opportunity” despite talkshow format risks. The spring series, running alongside but not replacing The Graham Norton Show, underscores her rise as one of primetime’s hottest talents as the BBC reforges its chatshow lineup.

articles.title: John Radcliffe obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Executive producer in the BBC’s continuing education department, he oversaw innovative adult educational programmes
articles.summary: John Radcliffe, BBC executive producer who died aged 90, led the 1980s computer literacy project that brought microcomputers into UK schools and homes via TV series and books, paving the way for IT teaching; as continuing education exec he produced adult learning programmes (All in the Mind), Troubles documentaries with Nuala O’Faolain and benefits drama For the Love of Albert; later headed the Open University production centre and BBC Select; Clare College history scholar, married twice and father of three, survived by six grandchildren and siblings.

articles.title: Mike Karin obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Journalist at Loaded magazine in the 1990s
articles.summary: Mike Karin, 59, began as a vinyl DJ in Ealing, qualified as a barrister (Gray’s Inn ’93), then joined Loaded in 1996, launching its website, editing online content and writing features. He freelanced for The Times, GQ, Vogue, Arena and YearZero (on Biggie Smalls). In 2003 he moved to Bangkok, became managing partner at Siam Legal, advising on extradition, telecoms disputes and a landmark 2012 UK Court of Appeal commercial agents case. He returned to Los Angeles, married Joanne Rogers in 2019. Survived by wife, parents, sister.

articles.title: As the US media floundered this year, I couldn’t help but think: ‘Thank God I’m at the Guardian’ | Moira Donegan
articles.trailText: Other media outlets have asked their writers to compromise, but the Guardian has never – and would never – ask me to pull a punch The Guardian has no billionaire or big corporate owner: funded by readers, our fierce independence is guaranteed. Please help us reach our year-end fundraising goal in these final crucial hours
articles.summary: Opinion editor Moira Donegan argues US media in 2024 scrambled between billionaire influence and Trump’s legal and regulatory coercion, with Murdoch, Bezos, Soon-Shiong and Ellison families reshaping coverage and outlets self-censoring to avoid lawsuits, FCC threats or owner displeasure, eroding journalistic quality and the mandate to serve readers. By contrast the Guardian’s reader-funded model, free of billionaire ownership, allows unflinching opinion and news coverage without political or commercial interference. Donegan celebrates her freedom to challenge the powerful week after week and urges readers to support the Guardian’s year-end fundraising appeal to protect independent journalism.

articles.title: From that bird guy to ‘bus aunty’: the real social media personalities rising above AI slop
articles.trailText: Online audiences seeking out authentic and passionate voices as antidote to AI-generated content
articles.summary: Social platforms are spotlighting everyday enthusiasts—like Gerald Stratford, the Cotswold pensioner whose red cabbage Instagram posts won a Gucci shoot, TikTok’s autism advocacy duo Tola and Kevin Andu (@raisingkevin_), ‘bus aunty’ Bemi Orojuogun and bird enthusiast Jack Baddams—over polished, AI-generated content. Creative directors and TikTok insiders credit the algorithm’s preference for genuine passion and educational value, citing niche creators worldwide—from US Vietnam-veteran twins Wayne and Dwayne Haneline to Italian Nonna Silvi and emergency doctor Solange Fugger—as proof that audiences crave authenticity.

articles.title: Bari Weiss defends decision to pull 60 Minutes episode on El Salvador prison
articles.trailText: CBS News editor-in-chief argues in memo that network’s priority was ‘comprehensive and fair’ coverage
articles.summary: Bari Weiss, CBS News editor-in-chief, withdrew a heavily promoted 60 Minutes investigation into alleged torture and due-process violations at an El Salvador prison, citing concerns over achieving “comprehensive and fair” reporting and securing a Trump administration response. The abrupt decision, explained in a Christmas Eve memo, drew internal backlash—correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi called it political—and public accusations of censorship amid CBS’s feud with Trump over interviews and a $16 m lawsuit settlement. Despite the pull, the segment surfaced online via Global TV. Weiss’s appointment by Paramount CEO David Ellison has fueled staff unease and media politicization concerns.

articles.title: Storytelling is an ancient human art, not a corporate invention | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Danyah Miller responds to a pass notes column about companies that are hiring people to ‘own the narrative’
articles.summary: Danyah Miller of the Society for Storytelling rebuts the notion that storytelling is a modern corporate tool, emphasizing its 30-year role championing oral narrative across schools, theatres, workplaces and care settings. She highlights that storytelling predates strategic communications, co-creating meaning between teller and listener, boosting cognitive function, memory and emotional resilience. Foundational for child literacy and vocabulary and vital to adult empathy, social bonds and wellbeing, storytelling remains an ancient human art, not a corporate invention.

articles.title: King Charles’s annual message is most watched TV show in UK on Christmas Day
articles.trailText: Nearly 7m tuned in to watch monarch praise ‘great diversity of our communities’ on 25 December
articles.summary: Overnight Barb data shows King Charles’s 2025 Christmas message—recorded in Westminster Abbey praising community diversity and urging compassion—was BBC/ITV/Sky News’ most-watched UK programme on 25 Dec with 6.56m viewers, matching last year’s figures. Gavin & Stacey’s finale topped Christmas Day ratings with 12.3m, the highest in 16 years. BBC One’s The Scarecrows’ Wedding (4.31m) and the final Strictly Come Dancing special with Tess Daly and Claudia Winkleman (4.24m) ranked second and third. EastEnders fell to eighth (2.85m), ITV’s festive 1% Club drew 2.75m, and BBC titles took nine of the top ten slots.

articles.title: Changing channels: TV streaming at turning point as most UK subscribers opt for ads
articles.trailText: Viewers hoping to cut bills driving switch from once-normal advert-free subscriptions now charging a premium
articles.summary: UK streaming subscriptions including ads will reach 26.5m by end-2025, overtaking ad-free plans which declined from 26.7m to 23.1m, driven by economic pressure and cheaper ad-supported tiers. Netflix’s 2022 launch of a lower-cost ad tier marked a strategic shift from its original ad-free model. Average monthly spend across leading platforms rose 14% to £64. The UK streaming ad market is set to hit £1.38bn, nearly half of linear TV’s £3.15bn, with Apple, Tesco, McDonald’s and Subway among top advertisers (Ampere Analysis).

articles.title: Unpublished ‘Tupperware erotica’ novel prompts fierce contest for TV rights
articles.trailText: Interest in Wet Ink by Abigail Avis is part of a trend for works by female authors among streamers and production companies
articles.summary: Wet Ink is a much-hyped novel by 33-year-old London author Abigail Avis, set in 1960s London. It follows Mitzy Barlow, a bored suburban housewife who hides erotic stories inside Tupperware containers during her parties, publishing them under the pseudonym Queen B. Despite its 2027 publication date, six major companies fiercely auctioned its TV rights—eventually won by Kudos, part of Banijay UK. This frenzy reflects a wider trend of female-authored books prompting premium streamer and producer bids worldwide.

articles.title: More than half a million pounds spent on influencers by UK government since 2024
articles.trailText: Figures from FoI request show increase in ministerial use of social media personalities to present campaigns
articles.summary: Since 2024 the UK government has spent £500k+ hiring 215 social-media influencers (126 in 2025, 89 in 2024) to promote environment, welfare and recruitment campaigns. The Department for Education led with £350k (53 vs 26 influencers year-on-year); DWP spent £120k on eight new creators; Business and Trade £39.7k on 17 personalities (e.g. Bella Roberts, Krish Kara); MoJ used 12 for prison and magistrate recruitment. FOI figures from agency Tangerine reveal a pivot to TikTok-native outreach amid cuts to Downing Street lobby briefings, prompting critics to warn this risks sidestepping robust media scrutiny.

articles.title: Edward Welsh obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Journalist and communications director in the public sector
articles.summary: Edward Welsh, 63, a former national newspaper journalist turned public-sector communications director, has died of bowel cancer. After reporting for the Sunday Times (1987–91), Daily Telegraph and various roles at The Times, a 1995 summer at Jimmy Carter’s conflict-resolution center prompted a shift to public service. His roles included communications at the London Assembly (2002), Local Government Association (2005), ATOC/Rail Delivery Group (2009–13) and Nursing and Midwifery Council (2018). Born in Orpington, raised in Islington and Cumbria, Bristol history graduate. Survived by partner Tony McLeod, adopted sons Amari and Jayden, sisters Cheryl, Sarah and his twin brother.

articles.title: Michael Vineall obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Marketing consultant who began his career as brand manager of bottled Guinness
articles.summary: Michael Vineall, who has died aged 87, was a marketing consultant best known for a 20-year Guinness career—from bottled Guinness brand manager in 1968 to board member of Guinness Superlatives and head of new product development—before freelancing in drinks, education and agrifood from 1983. Born in Ilford but raised in Yorkshire, he won a Leeds City scholarship to New College, Oxford, studying psychology, philosophy and physiology. Married to Mary in 1962, he lived in Buckinghamshire and later Grassington, enjoying cricket (a Leeds United season ticket-holder), jazz, motorsports, dogs, walks and theatre. A devout Anglican, he served decades on church councils and synods. A lifelong Guardian reader and Labour supporter known for forthright yet tolerant views, he is survived by his wife, children Anne and David, six grandchildren and brother Tony.

articles.title: 60 Minutes episode on brutal El Salvador prison, pulled from air by CBS, appears online
articles.trailText: Segment that Bari Weiss had removed provides in-depth look at the Centro de Confinamiento del Terrorismo prison
articles.summary: 60 Minutes’s unaired 14-minute investigation of El Salvador’s Cecot prison—torn from CBS by editor-in-chief Bari Weiss for 'additional reporting'—surfaced online after Global TV's accidental release. Inmate testimonies, HRW-backed State Department findings detail systematic torture, 24/7 lights, no bedding or clean water. Detainees shackled, beaten, confined in 'the island'. Backlash ensued from correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi and Senator Elizabeth Warren; CBS and Paramount pursue takedowns amid Trump's prior praise of the facility.

articles.title: ABC defends Laura Tingle and Sarah Ferguson amid ‘unfounded’ criticism of Bondi shooting coverage
articles.trailText: Hugh Marks calls questions about media’s role in wake of mass tragedy ‘understandable’ but says reviews must be ‘factual and accurate’
articles.summary: ABC managing director Hugh Marks has defended senior journalists Laura Tingle and Sarah Ferguson against 'unfounded' criticism over their coverage of the Bondi terror attack that killed 15 people on the first night of Hanukkah. Tingle was criticised for saying on a 16 Dec Politics Now podcast that the gunmen’s actions had 'nothing to do with religion,' while Ferguson faced backlash for asking ex-treasurer Josh Frydenberg on 17 Dec’s 7.30 whether his public comments were politically motivated. Critics including Liberal senator Sarah Henderson and ex-ABC board member Joe Gersh labelled the broadcasters’ remarks insensitive amid an antisemitic climate. Marks insisted the review must be factual and renewed the ABC’s commitment to responsible, inclusive reporting.

articles.title: Outrage after CBS pulls 60 Minutes segment on El Salvador’s Cecot prison
articles.trailText: Controversially appointed editor-in-chief Bari Weiss says: ‘I held that story and I held it because it wasn’t ready’
articles.summary: CBS abruptly pulled “Inside Cecot,” a 60 Minutes report on alleged torture at El Salvador’s mega-prison where the Trump administration sent deported Venezuelans. Correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi, whose team cleared the piece legally and editorially, accused leadership of political interference. Newly appointed editor-in-chief Bari Weiss defended halting the segment as “not ready,” citing a need for interviews with Trump officials. Critics—from CBS staff to Senators Brian Schatz and Ed Markey and commentator Kara Swisher—point to Paramount-Skydance corporate dealmaking and political appeasement undermining journalistic independence.

articles.title: CBS News delays 60 Minutes segment on El Salvador’s Cecot mega-prison
articles.trailText: Backlash after broadcaster announces investigation, due to air on Sunday night, ‘needs additional reporting’
articles.summary: 60 Minutes delayed its Inside Cecot report investigating alleged torture of over 250 migrants deported by the Trump administration to El Salvador’s Cecot mega-prison. CBS issued an editor’s note blaming the hold on “additional reporting,” sparking outcry from correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi and critics who allege political interference under new editor-in-chief Bari Weiss and parent Paramount’s ownership ties. U.S. senators, journalists and advocates denounced the move as censorship. The decision follows disputes over sourcing, White House comment requests and Skydance regulatory deals involving Larry Ellison.

articles.title: ‘I didn’t want to break it’: Linton Besser on the doubts and dilemmas in his first year presenting Media Watch
articles.trailText: Besser won a Walkley award for reporting that included investigating the ABC chair, but says there is still ‘lots of awkwardness’ in reporting on other journalists
articles.summary: Besser, a Walkley-winning investigative reporter, and EP Mario Christodoulou replaced Paul Barry and Tim Latham after 500 episodes, preserving the 36-year legacy of ABC's Media Watch. In their 15-minute Monday show they blended Besser's warm presenting style with Christodoulou's devil's advocate approach to deliver scoops—most notably investigating ABC chair Kim Williams's interventions and defence correspondent Andrew Greene's undisclosed company-funded trip—earning nominations and a Walkley for commentary. Balancing fairness and rigorous fact-checking, Besser navigates the awkwardness of scrutinizing colleagues, engages insider and public tips, and prioritizes transparent, middle-ground critique to uphold media ethics and ABC accountability.

articles.title: How the BBC can resist ‘entrumpification’ | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Enough of the orchestrated outrage – the BBC needs to be clear that there’s no systemic dishonesty at play, writes Anthony Lawton . Plus letters from Michele Ryan and Mike Pender
articles.summary: In letters responding to the Guardian’s 16 December editorial, Anthony Lawton warns of ‘entrumpification’ – the tactic of weaponising a single BBC error to allege systemic dishonesty. After acknowledging and apologising for a factual mistake, the BBC faced lawsuits, outrage and ‘fake news’ charges. Lawton urges a ‘both-and’ defence: admit the technical slip while affirming the corporation’s independence and evidence-based mission. He calls on the BBC, government and citizens to resist Trump-style attacks before democratic institutions weaken. Michele Ryan proposes a £1 public funding campaign to back the licence fee model, and Mike Pender quips about US entry bans for licence-payers.

articles.title: Can Dan Bongino regain his stature in the conservative media world?
articles.trailText: Trump says the former podcaster and radio host ‘wants to go back to his show’ after a brief spell as FBI deputy director
articles.summary: After failed electoral bids, Dan Bongino soared as a combative Fox News contributor and host of The Dan Bongino Show. Plucked by Kash Patel earlier this year to serve as FBI deputy director, he announced his departure next month. Donald Trump signaled Bongino’s imminent return to radio and podcasting, with replacement Vince Coglianese already hosting his Westwood One slot under a Silverloch Productions deal. Conservative insiders—from Eric Bolling to Talkers Magazine’s Michael Harrison—believe his Washington experience will boost his credibility, while peers like Laura Ingraham and Brian Rosenwald anticipate he’ll revert to his proven, provocative media persona.

articles.title: Trump Media announces $6bn merger plan with fusion power company
articles.trailText: TMTG, which owns president’s Truth Social platform, unveils link-up TAE Technologies to respond to AI boom
articles.summary: Trump Media and Technology Group, owner of Truth Social, will merge with fusion developer TAE Technologies in a $6bn deal, forming a 50:50 combined entity by mid-2026. TMTG plans to begin building the world’s first utility-scale fusion power plant in 2026 to power AI datacenters. Backed by Google and Chevron, TAE advances next-gen neutral beam fusion systems. TMTG’s revenues fell to $927,900 in Q3 with losses of $54.8m. Co-led by Devin Nunes and TAE’s Michl Binderbauer, the merger aims to secure energy supply, lower costs, and boost US AI and manufacturing.

articles.title: Warner Bros Discovery urges shareholders to reject Paramount’s $108.4bn takeover bid
articles.trailText: After WBD accused Paramount of misleading investors, the network assured it had ‘all necessary financing’ for the deal
articles.summary: Warner Bros Discovery has formally urged shareholders to spurn Paramount Skydance’s unsolicited $108.4 bn cash bid, labeling it undervalued, risky and backed by opaque financing. WBD’s board, chaired by Samuel Di Piazza Jr, argues its $82.7 bn sale of studios, HBO and streaming to Netflix offers superior certainty and value, warning of a $2.8 bn breakup fee if Paramount’s offer prevails. Paramount CEO David Ellison insists full financing is secured via the Ellison family, Affinity Partners, Saudi and Qatari funds. Regulators and investors now weigh Netflix’s pro-growth merger against Paramount’s all-cash structure amid Hollywood’s high-stakes takeover tussle.

articles.title: Jared Kushner’s firm exits takeover battle for Warner Bros Discovery
articles.trailText: Affinity Partners, key backer of hostile bid by Paramount, reportedly steps back following scrutiny of Kushner’s role
articles.summary: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has withdrawn from backing Paramount Skydance’s $108.4bn hostile bid for Warner Bros Discovery after scrutiny of Kushner’s involvement. Initially aligned with the Ellison family, Saudi Arabia’s PIF and Qatar’s QIA, Affinity stepped aside while still supporting a rival offer meant to replace WBD’s $82.7bn Netflix sale. WBD—owner of Warner Bros studios, HBO, HBO Max, CNN and Discovery—will soon advise shareholders on both bids. Federal regulators are set to review the deal, as Trump distances himself amid intensifying media scrutiny.

articles.title: BBC to fight Trump’s $10bn lawsuit, saying it should be dismissed
articles.trailText: Corporation will argue it did not have rights to air film in US and it did not cause serious reputational harm
articles.summary: BBC will move to dismiss Donald Trump’s $10bn defamation suit in Florida, arguing it lacked US broadcast rights for the Panorama episode and caused no reputational harm, as Trump won re-election and any US viewing via VPN or BritBox was negligible. Trump’s complaint claims misleading splicing of his January 6 speech damaged his brand and violated Florida’s Deceptive Trade Practices Act. The BBC, guided by its legal department and board, insists fighting is vital to protect editorial independence amid a charter renewal and leadership changes. Allies including Labour figures urged PM Starmer to back the BBC, while critics suggest settling would be cheaper.

articles.title: Donald Trump v the BBC: key points of the president’s claim
articles.trailText: We examine some of the allegations against the UK broadcaster in the $10bn lawsuit
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s $10 bn suit accuses the BBC of maliciously editing his Panorama speech to imply he urged violence, citing a whistleblower memo by Michael Prescott that labelled the programme “anti-Trump” and misleading despite no malice finding. He alleges VPN use in Florida brought the doc to U.S. viewers, creating jurisdiction. He claims the BBC abandoned objectivity and cites Liz Truss’s bias critique. Seeking damages for alleged reputational harm as a “violent insurrectionist,” Trump faces the BBC’s rebuttal that the 12-second edit was non-malicious, contextualized in an hour-long show, geo-restricted in the U.S., and had no measurable impact on voter opinion.

articles.title: Ministers look at depoliticising top BBC jobs as Farage rides high in polls
articles.trailText: Crucial talks begin on corporation’s future amid efforts to protect it from government influence
articles.summary: Ministers propose ending political board appointments and overhauling the BBC’s ten-year charter and licence fee amid Farage-fuelled criticism, to safeguard independence. A green paper flags funding reforms—from advertising and subscription top-ups to paywalls for older content—alongside a potential permanent or extended charter. It highlights declining licence uptake, generational shifts in media use and calls for protection from government influence while maintaining accountability. Robbie Gibb’s role and bias row spurred the review as Culture Secretary Nandy vows a future-proof, trusted BBC.

articles.title: BBC vows to defend itself in $10bn Donald Trump lawsuit
articles.trailText: President claims broadcaster ‘intentionally, maliciously and deceptively’ edited 6 January speech before Capitol attack
articles.summary: The BBC has vowed to defend a $10bn defamation suit brought by Donald Trump, who claims the broadcaster ‘intentionally, maliciously and deceptively’ edited his 6 January speech on Panorama. Trump seeks $5bn per count under defamation and Florida’s Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices Act. A BBC spokesperson reiterated its intention to contest the lawsuit. UK ministers including Stephen Kinnock and Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey publicly backed the BBC. The corporation has apologised for editorial errors but insists there is no legal basis for Trump’s broader claims. The case, filed in Florida, may hinge on its limited US reach.

articles.title: How might the BBC be funded if the licence fee is scrapped?
articles.trailText: As green paper on corporation’s charter renewal is launced, what funding options might be under consideration?
articles.summary: Government’s green paper on BBC charter renewal outlines six potential funding models if the licence fee is abolished, but insiders expect a last-minute licence-fee fudge. Options include: funding via general taxation (ruled out, likelihood 0/5); subscription model (unlikely, 1/5); on-air advertising (1/5); add-on fees for premium services (2/5); a household levy tied to council-tax bands (3/5); or maintaining the licence fee with limited reforms (favoured, 4/5). Decision process runs through 2027 amid universality and political concerns.

articles.title: Culture secretary to consider investigation into Telegraph takeover by Daily Mail owner
articles.trailText: Lisa Nandy will have to assess deal after formal request from the seller, Abu Dhabi-backed RedBird IMI
articles.summary: Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy must decide whether to trigger a public interest intervention notice after Abu Dhabi-backed RedBird IMI requested to transfer its right-to-buy option on the Telegraph titles to Daily Mail & General Trust. DMGT has secured a £500m funding package—cash, overdraft, NatWest loan—with £100m deferred until a 2027 Deutsche Bank bond. The PIIN, involving Ofcom and the CMA, will examine plurality and competition across DMGT’s combined portfolio (Telegraph, Mail, Metro, i, New Scientist). Analysts expect a 40-working-day probe but no phase-two or divestment, while DMGT pledges the Telegraph’s editorial independence and accelerated investment.

articles.title: It’s the media’s job to hold power to account. This year, too many got into bed with it instead | Arwa Mahdawi
articles.trailText: The lines between advertising, public relations and journalism have become dangerously blurred
articles.summary: Arwa Mahdawi criticizes the erosion of journalistic integrity as media outlets blur lines with advertising and PR under billionaire ownership. She recounts leaving adland for meaningful reporting, but sees the Washington Post’s Bezos ties silencing dissent, CBS’s Ellison owners and Bari Weiss’s pro-Israel slant, and widespread failure to scrutinize Gaza genocide coverage—such as unverified Hamas babies beheading claims. Mahdawi lauds the Guardian’s independence, progressive stance and urges reader support to preserve fearless, non-corporate journalism that truly holds power to account.

articles.title: Labour should not dismiss a social media ban for under-16s
articles.trailText: Letters: Australia is showing what is possible by not succumbing to the pressures of big tech. The UK needs to follow its lead, says Daniel Kebede
articles.summary: NEU general secretary Daniel Kebede counters Lisa Nandy’s claim that an Australian-style under-16 social media ban would criminalise minors, arguing concerns over prosecution distract from the real issue: tech companies’ exploitative, profit-driven algorithms harm young users. He cites rising anxiety, distraction, sleep loss, unending online bullying and extreme content among students. With 75% of UK public backing a minimum age of 16, parents demand systemic action, not guidance. Kebede urges the UK to emulate Australia’s ban, studying its rollout, and to urgently raise the age threshold from 13 to 16.

articles.title: Daily Mail owner secures funding for £500m takeover of Telegraph
articles.trailText: Details of financing structure to be reviewed by culture secretary and regulators before deal can proceed
articles.summary: DMGT, controlled by Lord Rothermere, has lined up £500 million to acquire the Telegraph from RedBird IMI in two instalments: £400 million immediately via increased NatWest debt and existing cash, and £100 million by 2027 using a Deutsche Bank–backed bond. The financing plan will be submitted to culture secretary Lisa Nandy and reviewed by the CMA and Ofcom before closing. RedBird, a US–UAE joint venture, sold after the UK banned foreign state media ownership. DMGT vows to keep Mail and Telegraph teams editorially independent and invest for global growth. Rival suitor Dovid Efune, with Jeremy Hosking backing, remains in contention.

articles.title: 4ZZZ community radio station celebrates 50 years of being Brisbane’s ‘voice against injustice and bullshit’
articles.trailText: Once ‘a lone voice of resistance’ in a conservative city, the community station has survived eviction and Queensland’s Joh Bjelke-Petersen government to deliver half a century of radical politics and local music
articles.summary: Since 1975 Brisbane community radio 4ZZZ has broadcast radical politics and local music, surviving eviction by the Joh Bjelke-Petersen government and reoccupying UQ before settling in a former Communist HQ in Fortitude Valley. Its walls preserve gig flyers and protest art; landmark shows include the Prisoners’ Show (now Locked In) that exposed Boggo Road Jail abuses, Queer Radio (1978), Dykes On Mykes and Tranzmission for trans voices. Sustained by volunteers and listener funding, 4ZZZ marks 50 years as a “voice against injustice and bullshit,” hosting events and a new history book.

articles.title: Comedian Robin Ince quits Radio 4 show, claiming BBC found his views ‘problematic’
articles.trailText: Ince says he resigned as co-host of Infinite Monkey Cage because of what he described as his lack of ‘obedience’
articles.summary: Comedian Robin Ince has resigned as co-host of BBC Radio 4’s long-running podcast The Infinite Monkey Cage after 16 years alongside Prof Brian Cox. Ince says BBC executives flagged his external views—support for the trans community, criticism of Donald Trump and even a gentle critique of Stephen Fry—as ‘problematic’ under impartiality rules. Following a meeting demanding ‘obedience’, he quit in September to retain freedom to speak on injustices. The BBC thanked him and will announce a successor soon.

articles.title: Dugal Nisbet-Smith obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Journalist and general manager of Times Newspapers in the 1970s
articles.summary: Dugal Nisbet-Smith, 90, New Zealand–born journalist and newspaper executive, began at the Southland Daily News before joining Fleet Street’s Daily Express. He later became assistant editor and managing director of the Barbados Advocate, challenging regional corruption. Returning to Britain in 1969, he led the Scottish Daily Record (1969–77) then served as general manager of Times Newspapers (1978–81), where his reforms triggered strikes that facilitated Rupert Murdoch’s takeover. Nicknamed "The Hawk," he advised the Aga Khan and directed the Newspaper Society (1983–97), clashing with Margaret Thatcher. Appointed CBE in 1996, he retired in 1997, pursuing painting, sculpture and All Blacks rugby fandom. He is survived by wife Ann, three children and grandchildren.

articles.title: Guardian’s former Gaza reporter acclaimed  at British Journalism Awards
articles.trailText: Malak A Tantesh lauded for her ‘vital coverage of a war most journalists were banned from witnessing’
articles.summary: Standing ovation at the British Journalism Awards, Malak A Tantesh—former Guardian Gaza correspondent—was named New Journalist of the Year and won the Marie Colvin Award after 18 months reporting from Gaza. Her dispatches detailed personal loss—bombed family home in Beit Lahia, skeletal children in hospital—and her own return journey following the January ceasefire. Judges praised her bravery, empathy and “vital coverage of a war most journalists were banned from witnessing.” Guardian editor Katharine Viner lauded her “brave and impactful reporting” in “most difficult” conditions.

articles.title: AI the main suspect after radio stations wrongly identify reporter as alleged violent offender | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Southern Cross Austereo investigate how Adelaide Advertiser journalist was wrongly named. Plus: awkward timing for ABC crime podcast
articles.summary: Southern Cross Austereo is probing how its new AI-assisted bulletins on Triple M and SAFM wrongly named Adelaide Advertiser journalist Dylan Hogarth as the hammer-wielding suspect, issuing on-air apologies and launching an internal review. The mishap underscores News Corp’s wider AI push—from ChatGPT illustrations in The Daily Telegraph to disclaimers on 3,000 weekly AI-generated local stories—and Michael Miller’s cautious endorsement of “smart” AI use. Meanwhile, ABC’s six-part podcast Unravel: Huntsman remains on air despite Greg Lynn’s overturned conviction. Radio National revamps its 2026 schedule: MediaLand is axed, Breakfast trimmed, Future Tense ends, and Global Roaming adds new co-hosts. ABC also appoints Chris Bendall to Insiders and Joel Tozer to Four Corners.

articles.title: Key whistleblower contradicts part of phone hacking case against Daily Mail
articles.trailText: Private investigator Jonathan Rees denies telling Doreen Lawrence he was involved in bugging her
articles.summary: Private investigator Jonathan Rees, a key witness in Prince Harry and Doreen Lawrence’s suit against Associated Newspapers, told Channel 4’s Dispatches he never admitted bugging Lawrence’s phones for the Daily Mail, contradicting her witness statement. While Rees says he saw evidence of surveillance and was offered involvement, he denies participation and has no documents. His concession may undermine claims ANL hired investigators for unlawful hacking, bugging and blagging. Another PI, Gavin Burrows, retracted a signed statement as forged. Dispatches also revealed funding links from James Stunt’s father and Hugh Grant for research into ANL’s practices.

articles.title: Letter: Brian Hayes obituary
articles.trailText: Vicki Leonard writes: Brian was ever-ready to debate bigotry on his LBC show, at a time when HIV/Aids and Section 28 were major talking points
articles.summary: Letter-writer Vicki Leonard recalls LBC broadcaster Brian Hayes (active 1976–86 under producer Lawrie Douglas, then 1986–90 with Leonard), who distinguished himself by calmly confronting bigotry on air during pivotal debates over HIV/Aids and Section 28 restrictions on LGBT discussion in schools and councils. His calm, kind and wise on-air manner, backed by Douglas’s production, encouraged thoughtful listener engagement. In his general calls hour, Hayes prepped with Susanne Bösche’s Jenny Lives With Eric and Martin to rebut homophobic callers and misinformation, shaping robust, informed public discourse and defending inclusive storytelling. His decade-long influence on radio debate left a legacy of fearlessly challenging Section 28 era censorship and advocating for LGBT rights on mainstream airwaves.

articles.title: Tony Dokoupil to serve as anchor of CBS Evening News
articles.trailText: After top editor Bari Weiss made outreach to anchors at other networks, CBS News decided to go with an internal candidate
articles.summary: Bari Weiss, after outreach to external talent, chose Tony Dokoupil, CBS Mornings co-host since 2019, as anchor of CBS Evening News starting Jan 5 to revitalize sagging ratings. At 44, Dokoupil embodies “old school journalistic values” amid trust challenges. His tenure follows a string of short‐lived anchors; he weathered a 2024 impartiality row over his combative Ta‐Nehisi Coates interview. CBS plans a cross‐country launch tour under his leadership.

articles.title: Gerry McCann calls for stronger press regulation as he recalls ‘monstering’
articles.trailText: Parents of Madeleine McCann among dozens to sign letter to PM urging him to revive second part of Leveson inquiry
articles.summary: Gerry McCann urged tougher UK press regulation, recalling how years-long ‘monstering’ by tabloids—misleading headlines, home intrusion, leaked case files—suffocated his family after Madeleine’s 2007 disappearance. He and wife Kate joined over 30 signatories in a letter to PM Keir Starmer demanding revival of Leveson’s second inquiry into media–police links, warning that unchecked abuses harm victims and impede justice. Culture secretary Lisa Nandy has ruled out a new Leveson phase, citing a changed online news landscape but welcomes discussions. McCann insists stronger oversight and redress mechanisms are vital as he continues to seek answers on his daughter’s fate.

articles.title: Channel 4 poaches new chief executive Priya Dogra from Sky
articles.trailText: Head of advertising and data at Sky will lead C4’s response to threatened Comcast takeover of ITV
articles.summary: Channel 4 has appointed Priya Dogra, Sky’s head of advertising, data and new revenue and former Warner Bros Discovery MD, as its new chief executive from early next year. Her recruitment follows Alex Mahon’s departure and interim leadership by Jonathan Allan. Dogra, who oversees Sky Media’s ad sales and joined after Sky’s partner underpayment scandal, arrives as Comcast, Sky’s owner, and ITV explore a £1.6bn tie-up that would give them 74% of the UK TV ad market versus Channel 4’s 26%. Any deal faces regulatory scrutiny; Channel 4 plans to oppose it. Reported by the Financial Times.

articles.title: ‘Don’t pander to the tech giants!’ How a youth movement for digital justice is spreading across Europe
articles.trailText: Gen Z are the first generation to have grown up with social media, they were the earliest adopters, and therefore the first to suffer its harms. Now they are fighting back
articles.summary: Gen Z, the first social-media native generation, launched #StopFisha in France in 2020 after revenge-porn accounts targeted peers, compelling Snapchat and TikTok to moderate. That momentum spawned Ctrl+Alt+Reclaim, Europe’s first youth-led digital justice movement demanding inclusion in policymaking, safer platforms, algorithmic transparency and data control. Activists such as Shanley Clémot McLaren, non-binary migrant Yassine and researcher Alycia Colijn expose intersecting harms—misogyny, hate speech, self-harm forums, addiction, surveillance and biased AI—driving anxiety, depression and deepfake pornography. They call for robust regulation beyond the Digital Services Act, an EU-funded public platform, consumer boycotts or logging off to reclaim social media for democracy and wellbeing.

articles.title: Trump warns Netflix’s $83bn deal for Warner Bros poses competition concerns
articles.trailText: President vows to get involved in controversial takeover described as ‘unprecedented’ by ex-chair of regulator
articles.summary: President Donald Trump warned Netflix’s proposed $83bn acquisition of Warner Bros could breach US competition thresholds by combining Netflix’s large subscriber base with HBO Max, potentially exceeding 30% of the streaming market. Speaking at the Kennedy Center, Trump pledged unprecedented White House involvement in the regulatory review overseen by the DOJ and EU authorities. Netflix, which disputes the market-share estimate by excluding platforms like YouTube, argues other players dilute its dominance. The deal, closing no earlier than Q3 2026, would give Netflix the Harry Potter, Batman and Game of Thrones franchises. Industry groups and Hollywood unions urge a block.

articles.title: Warner Bros Disaster? Netflix inks deal for troubled Hollywood giant
articles.trailText: David Zaslav, CEO of Warner Bros Discovery, promised ‘everyone’ would win by combining the storied Hollywood studios with his reality TV giant. Instead, many lost
articles.summary: After David Zaslav’s 2021 merger of Discovery and WarnerMedia promised ‘value’ for studios, investors and viewers, Warner Bros Discovery underperformed: cost cuts, stock decline and a hobbled streaming service. Zaslav, paid $51.9m last year, preserved his rich pay package yet failed to revitalize box-office hits beyond Barbie. Now Netflix will acquire Warner Bros and HBO assets for $82.7bn, pledging ‘more choice, opportunities and value.’ It follows a legacy of struggling tie-ups—from Time Inc. to AT&T—and reignites debate whether scale drives creativity or dilutes iconic brands. Its streaming arm, plagued by name changes, never secured a clear identity despite combining HBO Max and Discovery+.

articles.title: Vanity Fair and Olivia Nuzzi part ways amid scandal over RFK Jr relationship
articles.trailText: ‘Mutual’ decision follows controversy over relationship with presidential candidate and claims of ethical breaches
articles.summary: Vanity Fair announced it will let west coast editor Olivia Nuzzi’s contract expire at year-end, citing a mutual decision after allegations of journalistic and ethical breaches surfaced. Nuzzi’s ex-fiancé, journalist Ryan Lizza, accused her of undisclosed ties to Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential campaign and an undisclosed affair with former South Carolina governor Mark Sanford while covering him. The magazine conducted an internal review amid staff concern and limited commentary. Nuzzi’s memoir, American Canto, received mixed reviews, and she has acknowledged violating ethics rules and plans to avoid campaign reporting moving forward.

articles.title: Netflix agrees to buy Warner Bros Discovery studio and streaming business in $83bn deal
articles.trailText: Streaming service to gain control of studio behind Harry Potter and Batman, as well as HBO, home to The White Lotus and Game of Thrones
articles.summary: Netflix has agreed to acquire Warner Bros Discovery for $82.7bn in cash, valuing WBD’s studio and streaming assets—including Warner Bros franchises (Harry Potter, Batman, Superman), HBO series (Game of Thrones, Succession, The White Lotus), library titles (Friends, The Big Bang Theory) and UK/Ireland TNT Sports—for a combined streaming-studio powerhouse. Excluding debt, the deal values WBD at $72bn and will close after spinning off cable channels (CNN, TBS, TNT). Breakup fees of $5.8bn (Netflix) and $2.8bn (WBD) apply. Netflix projects $2–3bn annual savings by year three but faces intense regulatory scrutiny over competition and pricing power.

articles.title: Is Olivia Nuzzi’s nascent Vanity Fair comeback already over?
articles.trailText: Nuzzi is on a temporary contract that ends this month – but it remains unclear whether she’s staying after former fiance Ryan Lizza’s exposés about her
articles.summary: Under Mark Guiducci Vanity Fair hired political writer Olivia Nuzzi as a west-coast editor on a temporary contract ending this year. Her future is in doubt after ex-fiancé Ryan Lizza published multiple exposés alleging conflicts including her relationship with RFK Jr, an affair with Mark Sanford and ‘catch-and-kill’ breaches of source trust. Vanity Fair has issued only a brief statement and declined to comment on its ongoing review. Observers warn Guiducci’s aggressive talent strategy risks brand integrity. Nuzzi, who acknowledges ethical lapses, has not confirmed contract renewal.

articles.title: Daily Telegraph unveils Sydney’s Power 100 list. You won’t believe who’s on it | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Sky News host Sharri Markson among the News Corp luminaries to make the grade. Plus: ABC boss faces hostile Coalition duo in Senate
articles.summary: Daily Telegraph’s Sydney Power 100 ranks Sky News host Sharri Markson at #91 for Jewish community advocacy. News Corp luminaries dominate: exec chair Michael Miller (#5), Sky News CEO Paul Whittaker (#22) and Foxtel CEO Patrick Delany (#23). Lachlan Murdoch’s Bellevue Hill Christmas party honored list members; Clover Moore was absent. The Australian Education Union’s NAPLAN league table letter was spiked by News Corp. Veteran Peter Manning received a Walkleys Outstanding Contribution award. Private Media’s new agreement bars AI from replacing staff. ABC managing director Hugh Marks defended impartiality and disclosed a $2.6m legal cost for the Antoinette Lattouf dismissal case.

articles.title: New York Times sues Pentagon over Trump team’s limits on press reporting
articles.trailText: The paper says new rules limiting questions, movement and sourcing violate press freedoms and chill independent reporting
articles.summary: The New York Times filed a federal suit on Dec 4 in Washington DC against the Pentagon and Secretary Pete Hegseth, challenging an October policy that bars its Pentagon reporters from soliciting or reporting unapproved information, restricts their movement around headquarters and requires a 21-page acknowledgment. The Times, joined by peers that surrendered credentials, argues it violates the First Amendment by chilling independent coverage. A recent briefing featuring right-wing outlets highlighted the shift. Pentagon officials say the policy simply clarifies security rules. The suit seeks relief to restore full press access and sourcing.

articles.title: Bari Weiss to moderate CBS News town hall with Charlie Kirk’s widow Erika Kirk
articles.trailText: Exclusive: event, scheduled to air on 13 December, will focus on ‘grief, faith, politics, and more’, according to internal files
articles.summary: CBS News editor-in-chief Bari Weiss will moderate a town hall with Erika Kirk, widow of conservative activist Charlie Kirk, focusing on grief, faith and politics. Slated to air December 13 (recorded December 10 in NYC), the event marks Weiss’s first on-air programming since her October appointment by Paramount Skydance president David Ellison to broaden perspectives. Attendee applications probe conservatism, evangelical faith and personal loss. Weiss—who organized but did not appear in a Clinton–Rice interview—aims to recapture balanced journalism. Since her husband’s September 10 death, Erika Kirk has emerged as a vocal conservative advocating civic dialogue.

articles.title: Misha Glenny to present BBC Radio 4 ‘institution’ In Our Time
articles.trailText: Journalist, broadcaster and author, 67, will take over from Melvyn Bragg when series resumes next month
articles.summary: Misha Glenny, 67, award-winning journalist, broadcaster and author, will succeed Melvyn Bragg as presenter of BBC Radio 4’s In Our Time when it resumes on January 15. Bragg, 86, stepped down this September after 27 years and over 1,000 episodes exploring history, science, philosophy and culture. To mark the handover, Glenny and Bragg will feature on the Today programme on December 24. Glenny, known for reporting on post-communist Europe and presenting series such as The Invention Of…, brings international affairs expertise and podcast experience. BBC directors laud him as ideally positioned to continue the show’s legacy.

articles.title: Murdochs blessed Fox News plan to air 2020 election fraud claims, Smartmatic alleges
articles.trailText: In key hearing in defamation case, Fox counters that network simply covered allegations by Trump associates
articles.summary: At a Dec. 2, 2025 NY Supreme Court hearing in Smartmatic’s $2.7 bn defamation suit, the company’s lawyer argued Rupert and Lachlan Murdoch ordered Fox News to adopt Trump’s baseless 2020 election fraud narrative to regain conservative viewers lost after Fox called Arizona for Biden. Fox counsel denied any disinformation directive, citing Murdochs’ depositions and asserting hosts merely covered newsworthy claims. Smartmatic presented internal emails showing staff doubts and pro-Trump bias, while Judge Cohen signaled skepticism about proving actual malice before reviewing the broadcasts.

articles.title: Nike, Superdry and Lacoste ads banned in UK over ‘misleading’ green claims
articles.trailText: Advertising watchdog says all three firms misled shoppers by using term ‘sustainable’ in paid-for Google adverts
articles.summary: Advertising Standards Authority has banned Google ads by Nike, Superdry and Lacoste in the UK for using unsubstantiated terms like “sustainable materials,” ruling such absolute green claims ambiguous and misleading. The ASA said retailers must hold high‐level evidence for any future environmental assertions and clarify claim scope, accounting for product lifecycle impacts. Separately, it also banned a Betway Facebook gambling ad featuring a silhouette of F1 star Lewis Hamilton ahead of the British Grand Prix, finding it likely to appeal to under-18s and breach celebrity endorsement rules.

articles.title: Racial discrimination claim part of ‘deliberate campaign to discredit’ Mary Kostakidis, court documents allege
articles.trailText: Former SBS newsreader defends sharing two X posts about a speech by the late Hezbollah leader as fair comment on a matter of public interest
articles.summary: Court documents filed by former SBS newsreader Mary Kostakidis contend that racial discrimination proceedings initiated by Alon Cassuto, head of the Zionist Federation of Australia, aim to undermine and discredit her. Cassuto alleges she breached the Racial Discrimination Act by sharing on X a January 4 video of Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah’s speech with critical commentary on Israeli “genocide” and, on January 13, Nasrallah’s “from the river to the sea” quote. Kostakidis’ defence argues her posts were fair comment on a public issue, Zionism is political not ethnic, and Cassuto’s belated July complaint followed a press conference. A case management hearing is set for December 18 in Melbourne Federal Court.

articles.title: ‘Mansplaining’ was once a contender for word of the year. Here’s why we should stop using it
articles.trailText: ‘Rage bait’ is Oxford word of the year in 2025. But I think we should be able to decommission words that have brought more trouble than they’re worth, starting with the 2015 runner-up, writes Zoe Williams
articles.summary: Guardian columnist Zoe Williams decries Oxford’s 2025 Word of the Year, “rage bait,” as a term that legitimises content engineered to provoke anger online, exacerbate social silos and erode institutional trust. She parallels its choice to the euphemistic elevation of “ethnic cleansing” and argues for the decommissioning of harmful neologisms. Using “mansplain” — a 2015 Oxford runner-up and NYT WOTY pick — Williams illustrates how such words become overgeneralised, weaponised across political discourse and lose nuance, advocating for retiring words whose divisive impact outweighs their utility.

articles.title: ‘Rage bait’ named word of the year by Oxford University Press
articles.trailText: Existence of phrase – to describe content intended to make you angry – shows people are aware of manipulation tactics used online, says Oxford Dictionary publisher
articles.summary: Oxford University Press has named “rage bait” its 2025 word of the year after usage tripled in 12 months. Defined as online content engineered to provoke anger for clicks, the term underscores rising awareness of emotional manipulation tactics. OUP president Casper Grathwohl contrasts this outrage-driven engagement with last year’s “brain rot,” noting a cycle of provocation, algorithmic amplification and mental exhaustion. Coined on Usenet in 2002 to describe deliberate driver irritation, “rage bait” now labels viral posts and critiques the platforms and creators shaping online discourse.

articles.title: Virgin Media fined £23.8m for putting vulnerable customers at risk
articles.trailText: Company failed to protect thousands of people switching from analogue to digital landline, Ofcom rules
articles.summary: Ofcom has fined Virgin Media £23.8m for failing to safeguard vulnerable customers relying on telecare alarms when migrating 43,000 users from analogue to digital landlines between August 2022 and December 2023. The regulator found serious system failures in identifying and recording telecare users, resulting in disconnections that risked harm. Virgin self-reported the incidents, prompting a 30% discount, admitted failings and cooperated fully. It has since conducted manual record reviews, directly supported affected customers, enhanced communications, introduced in-home assistance, post-migration checks and is collaborating on a national awareness campaign. The penalty must be paid within four weeks.

articles.title: Sir Andreas Whittam Smith obituary
articles.trailText: Financial journalist who was the founding editor of the groundbreaking Independent newspaper in 1986
articles.summary: Sir Andreas Whittam Smith (1937–2025), a financial journalist educated at Oxford, launched and edited The Independent in 1986, pioneering its clean design, bold journalism and liberal stance. After senior roles at the Financial Times, The Times and Telegraph, he raised City capital and recruited top talent to challenge Fleet Street conventions. Overreach with a Sunday edition and shareholder interventions led to his 1994 ousting. He later liberalized film classification as BBFC president (1998–2002) and managed £6bn church assets as First Church Estates Commissioner (2013–17). He is survived by his wife, Valerie, sons Benedict and Mark, and three grandsons.

articles.title: GB News urged to cut ties with contributor accused of racism
articles.trailText: Rightwing activist claimed Commons deputy speaker Nusrat Ghani should be barred because she was born in Pakistan
articles.summary: Right-wing activist Lucy White – a GB News and TalkTV contributor and ‘global public policy advisor’ at lobbying firm Gunster Strategies – has faced demands to have her platform suspended after posting on X that Commons deputy speaker Nusrat Ghani, born in Kashmir, Pakistan, should be barred from parliament. Her xenophobic post was retweeted over 1,300 times, prompting condemnation from anti-Muslim campaign group Tell Mama and figures across parties. TalkTV said her views are her own and won’t rebook her; GB News insisted contributors’ personal social media do not reflect its values. Critics warn that explicit racism is increasingly normalised in British public life.

articles.title: Political interference in the BBC’s lectures | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Controversy over the Reith lectures is nothing new, says Mark Thompson , while Chris Barney believes the latest ‘censorship’ row could boost this year’s audience figures, and Alan Stone gives advice to BBC reporters
articles.summary: Three Guardian readers weigh in on alleged political censorship in the BBC’s Reith lectures: Mark Thompson recalls his father Edward P. Thompson’s 1980s Dimbleby lecture being vetoed by BBC executives, arguing longstanding political constraints on Auntie; Chris Barney applauds the BBC’s excision of Rutger Bregman’s line calling Trump “the most openly corrupt president in American history” for magnifying publicity and boosting audience interest; Alan Stone advises journalists to quote Joe Biden’s similar on-site remark to circumvent legal bans, underscoring tensions between editorial caution and free speech.

articles.title: Kerry O’Brien sounds the alarm for Australian media in thunderous Walkleys address | The Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Former 7.30 host takes Labor government to task for record on press freedom and pays tribute to Palestinian journalists. Plus: a roo in the news
articles.summary: At the 70th Walkley Awards, broadcaster Kerry O’Brien delivered a fiery plea for stronger press freedom, lambasting the Albanese government for unmet promises, paying tribute to Palestinian journalists’ casualties and warning “it can happen here.” Media Diversity Australia’s Paula Kruger excoriated the ABC’s all-male, all-white Sydney lineup. ABC chair Kim Williams urged “ground rules” to curb untrammelled AI development. Seven News was mocked after an AI-generated clip misidentified Australia’s Parliament as the US Capitol with a kangaroo. Cultural studies titan Prof Graeme Turner died at 78, and The Australian touted a “contest of ideas” campaign alongside Roy Morgan audience growth.

articles.title: Former Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre to be witness in trial brought by Prince Harry and others
articles.trailText: Judge warns he will not permit case ‘to descend into a wide-ranging public inquiry’
articles.summary: At a pre-trial hearing the High Court was told former Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre and ex-Mail on Sunday editor Peter Wright will be ANL’s early defence witnesses when trial opens 19 January. Prince Harry, Sir Elton John, David Furnish, Liz Hurley, Sadie Frost, Doreen Lawrence and Sir Simon Hughes accuse Associated Newspapers of unlawful information gathering—car bugging, private investigator blagging, phone hacking—allegations ANL denies. Justice Nicklin barred a “wide-ranging public inquiry” or ambush tactics, granted restricted use of Stephen Whittamore’s notebooks. The nine-week trial, with costs forecast at £38m, begins next year.

articles.title: BBC tells staff they cannot quote Trump line removed from Reith lecture
articles.trailText: Journalists not allowed to repeat Rutger Bregman’s corruption claims against US president in coverage of edit
articles.summary: BBC has barred reporters from quoting a line removed from Dutch writer Rutger Bregman’s Reith lecture, in which he labeled Donald Trump “the most openly corrupt president in American history,” citing legal advice and threats of a $5 billion lawsuit. Bregman and critics argue this self-censorship underscores deeper issues at the corporation after a Panorama mis-edit of Trump’s Capitol speech triggered resignations and legal fears. MPs and media figures condemned the move as weak-kneed and symptomatic of chaos within the BBC’s leadership.

articles.title: Toxic culture of distrust at BBC led to recent resignations, former deputy director says
articles.trailText: Mark Damazer says over-assertive board and executives feeling ‘embattled’ played into departures of Tim Davie and Deborah Turness
articles.summary: Mark Damazer, former BBC News deputy director, has blamed a toxic culture of over-assertive board members and embattled executives for the resignations of director general Tim Davie and BBC News chief Deborah Turness after a leaked memo by former adviser Michael Prescott alleging systemic bias on Trump, Gaza and trans issues. He criticised political appointments like board member Robbie Gibb—ex-Jewish Chronicle owner—for failing to recuse himself from Middle East coverage oversight and warned of insufficient self-reflection at the BBC board.

articles.title: All-male lineup take top slots at ABC Sydney after Chris Bath’s shock departure
articles.trailText: Director of audio concedes ‘there is always more to do’ on diversity as station staff express dismay at dearth of female presenters
articles.summary: After one year headlining Drive, TV star Chris Bath resigned from ABC Sydney, citing limited production support and to pursue passion projects, making way for Thomas Oriti. From 2026, Breakfast (Craig Reucassel), Mornings (Hamish Macdonald), Afternoons (James O’Loughlin & James Valentine) and Drive boast an all-male roster, provoking internal dismay and criticism from Dr Helen Vatsikopoulos and MP Cate Faehrmann. Director Ben Latimer conceded more diversity work needed despite ABC reporting 55.8% female staff, 57.1% women executives and a 10% gender pay gap. Staff lament chronic under-resourcing; Bath remains on a Sunday show.

articles.title: BBC has shown ‘leak and launch’ tactics work to destabilise it, ex-board member says
articles.trailText: Shumeet Banerji says Turness was forced out without allowing reasoned discussion between board members
articles.summary: Shumeet Banerji, a non-exec BBC board member, resigned, claiming he was excluded from key discussions that led to the abrupt removal of director-general Tim Davie and news boss Deborah Turness.
