Banerji’s letter says Turness was told mid-session she’d lost board confidence without prior debate, criticises chair Samir Shah for blocking reasoned discussion, and warns the leak of Michael Prescott’s memo — alleging systemic bias on Trump, Gaza and trans rights — validates a ‘leak and launch’ tactic that destabilises the BBC. Shah disputes Banerji’s account; Prescott’s critique is contested by a fellow adviser. BBC is searching for Banerji’s replacement.

articles.title: Reith lecturer accuses BBC of cowardice for censoring his remarks on Trump
articles.trailText: Dutch writer Rutger Bregman says claim that Trump was ‘most openly corrupt president in US history’ was removed
articles.summary: Dutch historian Rutger Bregman, invited as Reith Lecturer, accuses the BBC of ‘cowardice’ after it removed his claim that Donald Trump is “the most openly corrupt president in American history.” He says the edit, applied just before broadcast on legal advice amid Trump’s threatened $5bn lawsuit and White House pressure, amounted to self-censorship. Lib Dems and free-speech advocates have called for the full lecture—recorded in London, Liverpool, Edinburgh and the US—to be aired intact.

articles.title: Ofcom urges social media platforms to combat abuse and limit online ‘pile-ons’
articles.trailText: New guidance from UK regulator aims to combat misogynist abuse and ‘revenge porn’
articles.summary: Ofcom’s new guidance under the UK Online Safety Act urges social media firms to curb misogynist abuse and online “pile-ons” by limiting reply rates and deploying rate-limits on posts. It recommends hash-matching tech to detect and remove non-consensual intimate images (“revenge porn”), plus prompts before posting abuse, user “time-outs”, ad demonetisation for offenders, and bulk block/mute tools. Though voluntary, platforms face a 2027 compliance report and possible tougher regulation. Ofcom CEO Dame Melanie Dawes and campaigners warn firms to act or risk statutory measures.

articles.title: Bevan Shields steps down as Sydney Morning Herald editor, chief reporter Jordan Baker named as replacement
articles.trailText: Shields told SMH staff in an email that working in the role had been the honour of his life
articles.summary: After four years at the helm, 40-year-old Bevan Shields has resigned as editor of the Sydney Morning Herald to focus on his health, returning after a break as a senior writer. Shields, credited by Nine’s executive editor Luke McIlveen with launching a Parramatta bureau, expanding political, education, transport and health coverage and growing investigations, called his editorship “the honour of my life.” Chief reporter Jordan Baker—a Herald veteran since 2005 with stints as education editor, crime and transport reporter and former Australian Women’s Weekly news editor—will assume the editor role early next year.

articles.title: Claims of systemic problems with BBC news coverage disputed by former adviser
articles.trailText: Caroline Daniel tells MPs leaked memo by Michael Prescott that sparked resignations at BBC did not provide full picture
articles.summary: After Michael Prescott’s leaked memo alleging systemic bias in BBC news on subjects from Trump to Gaza prompted director-general Tim Davie and Deborah Turness to resign, former EGSC adviser Caroline Daniel told MPs Prescott’s account was personal and incomplete, praising robust internal debates and auditing of impartiality. Prescott maintained follow-up on concerns was weak but denied institutional bias. Board member Robbie Gibb, under scrutiny for political links, and chair Samir Shah also defended the BBC’s impartiality. MPs were unconvinced by governance, prompting plans to revamp the external advisory committee and add a journalism deputy for the new director-general.

articles.title: ‘Blind spots’ but no institutional bias: key points after MPs question senior BBC figures
articles.trailText: A parliamentary select committee has questioned Michael Prescott, the adviser who wrote the memo that led to the resignation of the BBC’s director general, Tim Davie
articles.summary: During a Culture, Media and Sport select committee session, Michael Prescott, author of the leaked memo that led to DG Tim Davie and News head Deborah Turness’s resignations, maintained the BBC has no institutional bias but suffers ‘incipient’ systemic editorial flaws. Prescott’s “personal highlights” memo, not a full internal review, critiqued coverage of Trump, Gaza and diversity; MPs were told of board splits over whether Panorama’s Trump edit misled viewers. Robbie Gibb defended his impartiality, and advisers urged appointing a deputy DG as Trump’s $1bn lawsuit threat looms.

articles.title: What happened at Fox News after the 2020 election? Documents reveal new details
articles.trailText: Tens of thousands of documents were released as part of Smartmatic’s defamation lawsuit against the network
articles.summary: Smartmatic’s $2.7 billion defamation suit has unsealed 60,000+ pages of Fox News internal texts and emails, revealing that Sean Hannity privately expected Trump to concede and regretted the network’s Covid messaging; Rupert Murdoch defended Fox’s election coverage and urged Trump to accept results; Jeanine Pirro lobbied the RNC to buy her book; Lou Dobbs complained Marjorie Taylor Greene was “black-balled”; Steve Bannon pushed Maria Bartiromo to run for Senate; board members Paul Ryan and Anne Dias criticized on-air errors; and staff debated Tucker Carlson interviewing Lachlan Murdoch amid post-election fallout.

articles.title: Fox Corp chief told Sean Hannity that Trump could not go on air in 2020 if he attacked network
articles.trailText: Even before the 2020 election, tensions were high between Fox News executives and Trump, new documents show
articles.summary: Court documents from Smartmatic’s defamation suit reveal deep 2020 rifts between Fox News and Trump. On October 1, Lachlan Murdoch texted Sean Hannity that Trump would be barred from Fox if he used airtime to attack the network. After Fox called Arizona for Biden, Hannity noted intense backlash—“Trump people hate Fox.” Internal emails show Rupert Murdoch fretting over audience losses, debating whether to reverse the Arizona call, and later acknowledging election fraud claims fueled January 6. Both Murdochs defended reporting Trump’s allegations while Fox denies Smartmatic’s damages claims and prepares for summary judgment next month.

articles.title: BBC in crisis: key questions to answer as Commons select committee meets
articles.trailText: MPs will examine Michael Prescott’s claims of liberal bias in coverage of Gaza, racial diversity and trans issues
articles.summary: BBC director-general Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness resigned after board splits over a memo from former external adviser Michael Prescott alleging systemic liberal bias in coverage of the US election, Gaza, racial diversity and trans issues. MPs on the Culture, Media and Sport committee will hear from Prescott, Tory board member Robbie Gibb, chair Samir Shah, external adviser Caroline Daniel and board member Caroline Thomson. Key questions include whether Prescott’s concerns were ignored, the role of David Grossman’s research and a possible right-wing campaign, delayed board response, Shah’s governance and discord within the committee.

articles.title: Theresa May and Cate Blanchett to guest edit BBC Today programme
articles.trailText: Former PM to examine issue of trust in politics and Oscar-winning actor’s show will discuss AI
articles.summary: Former PM Theresa May will guest-edit BBC Radio 4’s Today on Dec 31, probing eroded trust in politics, domestic violence, modern slavery, her own knighthood of Geoffrey Boycott and her love of cricket. Cate Blanchett takes the helm on Dec 27 to examine AI’s impact on women in film, sustainable fashion, refugee policy and the therapeutic value of gardening. AI entrepreneur Mustafa Suleyman follows on Dec 29 to debate superintelligence safeguards. Other guest editors include Melvyn Bragg, Tom Holland and Sir James Dyson.

articles.title: BBC to expand standards panel and add deputy director general after bias row
articles.trailText: Planned overhaul of editorial guidelines committee would dilute influence of Tory board appointment Robbie Gibb
articles.summary: As the BBC reacts to the sudden resignations of director general Tim Davie and news boss Deborah Turness—triggered by a leaked memo from former adviser Michael Prescott alleging liberal bias on Trump, Gaza and trans rights—it will overhaul its Editorial Guidelines and Standards Committee (EGSC). Plans include expanding the EGSC to dilute the influence of Conservative board member Robbie Gibb and creating a deputy director-general role to support Davie’s successor. The measures follow MP scrutiny of Prescott, Gibb and chair Samir Shah, the resignation of board member Shumeet Banerji, and mounting union and political calls to curb party appointments and safeguard impartiality.

articles.title: Australia’s under-16s social media ban is weeks away. How will it work – and how can I appeal if I’m wrongly banned?
articles.trailText: Tech platforms will need to deactivate accounts for users under 16 and stop teens from making accounts until they are that age, or face fines of up to $50m
articles.summary: From 10 December, Australia’s world-first law forces major social platforms—Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat, X, YouTube, Reddit, Twitch and Kick—to deactivate existing under-16 accounts, bar new sign-ups until users turn 16 or face fines up to A$49.5m. Exempted services include YouTube Kids, Google Classroom, LinkedIn and Pinterest. Platforms must deploy multi-layered age checks—ID plus behavioural signals or facial estimates—to identify minors. Affected users can download or archive content and freeze or delete accounts until they reach 16. Mistakenly flagged adults can appeal via selfie, ID or bank-card verification. YouTube threatens a high-court challenge; other big players have pledged compliance.

articles.title: Lord Rothermere’s Telegraph takeover strengthens UK media’s rightwing tilt
articles.trailText: Many fear competition and diversity will be diminished as Daily Mail owner wins race to buy newspaper
articles.summary: Lord Rothermere’s Daily Mail and General Trust agreed a £500m takeover of the Daily Telegraph from RedBird IMI, ending a sale saga since 2023 triggered by Barclay family debts. The deal, which awaits culture secretary Lisa Nandy’s review, follows RedBird’s withdrawal amid foreign-ownership concerns. Rothermere, already holding 9%, will extend DMGT’s portfolio to five national titles. Critics including Tom Baldwin and Neil Kinnock warn this consolidation deepens a rightwing media monopoly, diminishing competition, plurality and democracy despite DMGT’s pledge of editorial independence. Observers note Labour’s muted response undermines its stance on media diversity.

articles.title: Daily Mail owner strikes £500m deal to buy Telegraph titles
articles.trailText: Acquisition likely to trigger in-depth investigation by regulator after agreement between DMGT and Redbird IMI
articles.summary: Lord Rothermere’s Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) has agreed a £500m deal to buy the Telegraph titles from RedBird IMI—controlled by Abu Dhabi’s Sheikh Mansour—entering exclusivity and aiming for swift closure. The acquisition, triggering Ofcom and CMA probes, creates a right-leaning media group alongside DMGT’s Metro, i and New Scientist. To allay competition concerns, analysts expect DMGT to divest i and Metro. DMGT vows separate, independent editorial teams and compliance with the UK’s new foreign state influence regime—no state capital funds the purchase. The culture secretary will review the sale under public interest rules. The deal follows RedBird Capital’s aborted bid and caps Rothermere’s long-standing bid for the Daily Telegraph.

articles.title: Meet the conservative lawyer causing headaches for major news networks
articles.trailText: Critics are concerned that Daniel Suhr, the head of a conservative legal group, may be pulling the strings behind many of the Trump FCC’s moves
articles.summary: Since September 2024, Daniel Suhr, president of the two-person Center for American Rights, has leveraged his alliance with Trump-picked FCC Chair Brendan Carr to revive and file media bias complaints—targeting CBS’s 60 Minutes Harris interview, ABC’s presidential debate coverage and Jimmy Kimmel’s shows—leading to forced transcript releases, bias-ombudsman provisions in major mergers like Paramount-Skydance and demands to eliminate all DEI initiatives. Critics warn his rapid influence raises questions about political agendas reshaping broadcast regulation under Carr.

articles.title: BBC board member quits after being ‘cut out’ of talks over liberal bias claims
articles.trailText: Shumeet Banerji was away during crucial discussions that led to resignation of director general and BBC News chief
articles.summary: Shumeet Banerji, BBC non-executive director, has resigned, alleging he was excluded from board talks that forced director-general Tim Davie and BBC News chief Deborah Turness to quit after Michael Prescott’s memo accused the broadcaster of liberal bias in Trump, Gaza and transgender coverage. Citing governance failings under chair Samir Shah and highlighting Robbie Gibb’s bias claims, Banerji’s exit removes a counterweight ahead of the DG replacement. His departure coincides with Prescott and Gibb’s Commons scrutiny and calls for Gibb’s removal; the BBC is already searching for a successor.

articles.title: BBC is losing £1bn a year in potential licence fee revenue, say MPs
articles.trailText: Public accounts committee calculates cost of households either evading the fee or saying they don’t need one
articles.summary: The Commons committee reports BBC loses over £1bn annually from licence fee evasion and households claiming no need. MP analysis finds a 12.5% evasion rate (£550m) and 3.6m non-users (£617m). Visits to unlicensed homes rose 50% but prosecutions fell 17%. Facing charter talks and leadership upheaval after DG Tim Davie’s resignation, the BBC explores funding reform amid critics questioning the fee’s relevance in a digital era. MPs urge modernised enforcement focused on online viewing.

articles.title: Ofcom at risk of losing public trust over online harms, says Liz Kendall
articles.trailText: Technology secretary fears digital frontier may be outpacing regulator, with AI chatbots a particular concern
articles.summary: Technology secretary Liz Kendall warned Ofcom that failing to fully enforce the Online Safety Act risks eroding public trust, amid delays in implementing key protections against harmful content. She highlighted threats from AI chatbots linked to youth suicides and pressed for their regulation under the law. Ofcom recently fined a "nudify" app £50,000 for exposing children to pornography. Meanwhile, the UK launched an AI growth zone aiming to secure £10bn investment and create 5,000 jobs, backed by £100m for domestic chip design startups as ministers seek more homegrown tech.

articles.title: Why Sky Sports’ TikTok channel for female fans was a disaster | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Sports marketing needs a fundamental shift to reflect how women and girls enjoy sports, says Kate Dale
articles.summary: Kate Dale, director of marketing at This Girl Can and Sport England, argues that Sky Sports’ new TikTok channel Halo failed because it stereotyped female fans as a single ‘girlie’ group and leaned on trend-chasing aesthetics. Dropped after just three days amid sexism accusations, Halo exposed how sports marketing still reduces women’s passion for sport to one narrow trope. Dale calls for a fundamental shift toward authentic, varied representation of women and girls in physical activity—showcasing diverse backgrounds, abilities and motivations to foster genuine belonging.

articles.title: US watchdog led by Trump ally investigates BBC Panorama edit of January 6 speech
articles.trailText: Brendan Carr, head of FCC, asks if programme ever aired in US which is seen as key to any future litigation
articles.summary: The FCC, led by Trump ally Brendan Carr, has asked BBC director-general Tim Davie whether a Panorama episode splicing two January 6 Trump speech clips ever aired in the US, a focal point for Trump’s threatened $5bn defamation suit. The inquiry comes after the BBC apologised, and Davie and news head Deborah Turness resigned following a complaint by adviser Michael Prescott. BBC chair Samir Shah vows to fight. Carr has no formal FCC jurisdiction but has also queried PBS and NPR partnerships. Experts like NYT’s David McCraw say the BBC should be confident if no US broadcast occurred.

articles.title: Ita Buttrose airs unapologetic views on immigration as Albanese returns to ABC Hard Chat a decade on | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Former ABC chair says Australia has allowed ‘divisive groups’ into the country. Plus: national broadcaster unveils plans for more short-form news video
articles.summary: Ita Buttrose said on her memoir tour that multicultural Australia is not working as divisive groups have been allowed in, urging immigrants to embrace Australian ways and proud she never revealed her politics. Separately PM Anthony Albanese returned to ABC’s Hard Chat for a one-off interview. ABC MD Hugh Marks unveiled the 2026 slate of 60 Australian series including robodebt drama Shakedown, Evonne Goolagong biopic, Dustfall and a High Court documentary. ABC plans more short-form social news via News Loop, is probing reporter Fazal’s podcast conduct, and the Herald Sun apologised to Sam Groth.

articles.title: Edinburgh TV Festival could leave Edinburgh
articles.trailText: Organisers look at other UK venues amid concerns over costs and industry’s lack of working-class voices
articles.summary: Organisers of the long-running Edinburgh TV Festival are reviewing whether to relocate the annual event—traditionally held amid Edinburgh’s summer festivals—citing high accommodation costs and barriers for working-class participants. They’re soliciting bids for the 2027 edition to “broaden access,” with London effectively excluded, though Edinburgh may reapply. Owned by The TV Foundation, the festival aims to boost inclusion after criticism, notably James Graham’s call to address class imbalance. Rising summer hotel rates, pandemic-era industry squeeze and streaming-driven changes have worsened freelance financial pressures.

articles.title: The infidelity saga of RFK Jr, Nuzzi and her ex is unspooling: ‘It’s like they’ve opened all their trench coats’
articles.trailText: The rollout of reporter Olivia Nuzzi’s memoir has led to Ryan Lizza airing out her alleged affairs – and is fueling a dangerous stereotype about journalists
articles.summary: Olivia Nuzzi published excerpts of her memoir revealing an emotional affair with Robert F. Kennedy Jr., while ex-fiancé Ryan Lizza countered with a self-published essay accusing her of a separate liaison with Mark Sanford. The public back-and-forth between two high-profile political reporters has fueled schadenfreude in media circles, revived stereotypes about journalists’ ethics, and risked further eroding public trust. Critics warn such personal exposés blur conflicts of interest, reinforce tropes of corruptible female reporters, and underscore journalism’s broader credibility crisis amid dwindling audience confidence.

articles.title: Peers call for independent body to take control of Telegraph sale
articles.trailText: Lords say culture department has mishandled process and suggest CMA or Cabinet Office oversee new auction
articles.summary: House of Lords peers have urged culture secretary Lisa Nandy to override RedBird IMI’s stewardship of the Telegraph sale—dominated by UAE funding—and transfer the auction to an independent body like the Competition and Markets Authority or Cabinet Office, citing DCMS mismanagement after RedBird Capital’s withdrawal. Nandy could invoke new Foreign State Influence powers to force a market-led sale. Politically sensitive due to a potential £150m loss for Abu Dhabi-backed IMI, the process could attract bids from Sir Paul Marshall, DMGT or other investors under fresh competition scrutiny.

articles.title: Mishal Husain calls for end to ministers picking BBC board members amid ‘existential crisis’
articles.trailText: Former BBC journalist says change needed to win back public trust, as executives prepare to be questioned by MPs
articles.summary: Former BBC anchor Mishal Husain warns of an ‘existential’ crisis at the corporation as MPs prepare to quiz executives following the resignations of DG Tim Davie and CEO Deborah Turness. She criticises political appointments—like ex-Tory press secretary Robbie Gibb—arguing government-controlled board selections undermine public trust. Husain calls for splitting the DG’s chief executive and editor-in-chief roles and implementing non-partisan board appointments. At next week’s culture committee hearing, chair Samir Shah and non-executives Gibb and Caroline Thomson will face questions alongside advisory editor Michael Prescott, whose leaked report on a misleading Trump Panorama clip spurred resignations and a threatened $1bn–$5bn lawsuit from Trump.

articles.title: Valvoline, bourbon and a touching tribute from Russell Crowe: radio star John Laws farewelled at state funeral
articles.trailText: John Howard, billionaire Lindsay Fox and Dawn Fraser among mourners at service for broadcaster known as ‘the Golden Tonsils’
articles.summary: Academy Award winner Russell Crowe led tributes at broadcaster John Laws’s state funeral in Sydney’s St Andrews Cathedral, mixing irreverence—recalling a Wild Turkey bourbon gift to Crowe’s son and Laws’s 1999 cash-for-comment scandal—with respect for his “Golden Tonsils” baritone and seven-decade career. Eulogist Paul Warren praised Laws’s versatility—from selling Valvoline and Toyotas to singing on Skippy—92 consecutive radio survey wins and interviews with 16 prime ministers. Among 800 mourners were John Howard, Lindsay Fox, Dawn Fraser, Chris Minns and Governor Margaret Beazley, while Reverend Michael Jensen celebrated his common touch and kindness mantra: “Be kind to each other.”

articles.title: Hugh Marks decries ‘opportunistic’ attacks on the ABC – but concedes broadcaster blew it with Bluey
articles.trailText: ABC managing director tells National Press Club comparisons between BBC program edit and Four Corners episode are not legitimate
articles.summary: Hugh Marks, ABC managing director, lambasted Sky News and The Australian for “opportunistic” comparisons between ABC’s Four Corners edit of Trump’s 6 January 2021 speech and the BBC Panorama scandal, deeming them illegitimate. He conceded ABC failed to monetise Bluey—co-produced with the BBC—which generates about $300 million a year in licensing. Marks highlighted the ABC’s independent governance, urged a shift from defensiveness to owning mistakes, and welcomed reasonable scrutiny while shielding staff from distracting noise.

articles.title: The ABC has been attacked in News Corp outlets for its editing of Trump’s Capitol speech. Did it do the same as the BBC?
articles.trailText: The ABC has vehemently denied allegations of unethical practice over a 2021 Four Corners program. Here’s what Trump said, and what it said
articles.summary: Sky News Australia and The Australian, led by Chris Kenny, allege a 2021 Four Corners episode distorted Trump’s Jan 6 speech, mirroring the BBC Panorama splice scandal. Unlike Panorama—which joined sentences 54 minutes apart to imply an incitement to violence—Four Corners removed a 10-second repeated sentence from a single grab. ABC MD Hugh Marks, news director Justin Stevens and Ombudsman Fiona Cameron deny any misleading edit. Media Watch and ex-ABC editorial director Alan Sunderland confirm the context remains intact. Critics persist, urging ABC leadership resignations and a Senate inquiry.

articles.title: Ofcom receives complaints over GB News item on defendants’ ‘foreign-sounding names’
articles.trailText: Lib Dem MP says way figures were compiled on ‘non-British-sounding’ surnames in court was ‘frankly racist’
articles.summary: GB News aired an unscientific segment by Martin Daubney presenting solicitor Marcus Johnstone’s six-week survey of “non-British-sounding” surnames among defendants at nine Crown Courts—reporting averages of 51% in Birmingham, 55% in Bradford, 56% in Snaresbrook and 31%–41% among sex offence charges. Lib Dem MP Anna Sabine has filed an Ofcom complaint alleging “unverified and frankly racist” methodology that risks stoking prejudice, pointing to the broadcast code’s requirement for verifiable data. GB News contests the complaint as politically motivated. Ofcom says it is assessing breaches while Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy urges stronger action on misleading content.

articles.title: More details of crime suspects may be released to try to stop misinformation
articles.trailText: Information such as age and nationality will generally not constitute contempt of court under proposed laws
articles.summary: The Law Commission for England and Wales proposes allowing police and media to publish suspect details—name, age, nationality, ethnicity, religion or immigration status—once a person is charged, shifting ‘active proceedings’ from arrest to charge. Under its draft contempt reforms, publication is safe unless it poses a substantial risk of prejudicing a trial. Prompted by misinformation after last year’s Southport murders and criticism of Merseyside Police for withholding ethnicity, the measures aim to fill information vacuums, deter false narratives and clarify online publication rules. Guidance from the NPCC and College of Policing already echoes these reforms. Part Two of the review, on procedure and sanctions, arrives in 2026; government response is pending.

articles.title: Rachel Cooke obituary
articles.trailText: Journalist, literary critic, food writer and columnist whose work graced the Observer for 24 years
articles.summary: Rachel Cooke (1969–2025) was a Sheffield-born journalist, literary critic and food writer whose witty, erudite columns enlivened The Observer for 24 years. Educated at Oxford, she joined the paper’s Review section in 2001 and won Interviewer of the Year at the British Press Awards in 2006. Her sharp interviews—from Rick Stein to Wes Streeting—and vibrant book and food criticism, later anthologised in Kitchen Person (2023) and The Virago Book of Friendship (2024), showcased her clarity of judgment. Author of Her Brilliant Career (2013), she married novelist Anthony Quinn and worked until a cancer diagnosis. She died aged 56.

articles.title: Bias claims and Trump’s lawsuit against the BBC | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Judgmental assertions of bias should not supplant careful analyses of evidence, writes Prof Peter Ayton . Plus letters from Peter Williams , Richard Evans , David Bell , Sam White and Ste Thomas
articles.summary: A batch of letters criticises both unsubstantiated bias claims against the BBC and its critics’ failure to cite rigorous research. Prof Peter Ayton highlights 1975–2000 IBA/ITC surveys showing most viewers saw no BBC slant and more perceived pro-Tory than pro-Labour bias, and cites a 2013 Cardiff study finding the BBC reflects a Conservative, Eurosceptic, pro-business worldview. Other correspondents lampoon Trump’s “100% fake news” remark and urge the BBC to countersue, propose airing his January 6 speech unedited, demand sackings plus a gold-plated “pram rattle,” speculate a state-visit offer might end his suit, and threaten licence-fee boycotts while clinging to 6 Music.

articles.title: BBC should not pay Trump any money, says former director general Tony Hall
articles.trailText: Not ‘appropriate’ to use licence fee payer’s money to pay US president after threat to sue for up to $5bn, says peer
articles.summary: Former BBC DG Lord Tony Hall said the broadcaster must refuse Donald Trump’s demand for licence-fee payers’ cash after his threatened $5bn suit over a misleading Panorama edit of his 6 January 2021 rally speech. Hall labelled the edit a “serious error” and warned that paying Trump would misuse public funds, while lamenting damage to journalists’ impartiality. The row has already cost DG Tim Davie and News chief Deborah Turness their jobs, and follows fresh claims of a similar Newsnight edit. The BBC has apologized, pulled the Panorama episode, and is investigating, amid pressure from MPs and ministers.

articles.title: Sky Sports ditches ‘unbelievably sexist’ TikTok channel Halo after three days
articles.trailText: Female-targeted account pulled after sports fans criticise posts referencing matcha, Barbie and ‘hot girl walks’
articles.summary: Sky Sports launched Halo as a TikTok ‘lil sis’ channel for young female fans, but its pink-heart branding, references to matcha, Barbie and ‘hot girl walks,’ and video of male stars like Rayan Cherki and Erling Haaland prompted accusations of patronising sexism. Women’s sports sites GirlsontheBall and She Kicks slammed the tone-deaf copy and imagery. After three days of online derision, Sky admitted it “didn’t get it right,” pulled Halo, and vowed to learn from the misstep and create more inclusive spaces, while fans celebrated the channel’s swift demise.

articles.title: Tributes paid to ‘fearless and funny’ Observer journalist Rachel Cooke who has died aged 56
articles.trailText: Cooke, who worked for the Observer for 25 years and was described as its ‘backbone’, was diagnosed with cancer earlier this year
articles.summary: Observer journalist Rachel Cooke died aged 56 this November after a cancer diagnosis earlier in 2025. A Sheffield-born Oxford graduate, she began at the Sunday Times before a 25-year tenure at the Observer, where colleagues hailed her as the paper's “backbone.” Versatile and prolific, she delivered fearless commentary, piercing interviews, campaigning social reporting, erudite book reviews, taste-making food columns—inspired by her Sunderland grandmother—and courageous foreign reportage. In 2023 she published Kitchen Person. Tributes from Tim Adams, Jane Ferguson and Simon Hattenstone praised her humour, intellect and relentless work rate. She is survived by husband, writer Anthony Quinn.

articles.title: Ex-BBC boss leads calls for end to political appointments to board
articles.trailText: Tony Hall urges government to bolster BBC’s independence as MPs and union seek Robbie Gibb’s removal from board
articles.summary: Tony Hall, former BBC director-general, has led pressure to end political appointments to the BBC board after Theresa May’s ex-communications chief Robbie Gibb was accused of pressing internal bias complaints. MPs, BBC staff and union Bectu demand Gibb’s removal amid claims he pressured the editorial guidelines committee, prompting resignations of Tim Davie and Deborah Turness. Culture secretary Lisa Nandy is examining charter renewal reforms to remove political influence and consider a permanent 10-year charter. Insiders dispute Gibb’s dominance; the BBC vows to review standards and dilute his role on the EGSC amid broader independence safeguards.

articles.title: Naga Munchetty reportedly under formal BBC investigation over alleged bullying
articles.trailText: Previous claims against BBC Breakfast presenter have been escalated to full investigation, according to the Sun
articles.summary: BBC Breakfast presenter Naga Munchetty is under a formal BBC HR investigation after bullying claims were escalated, according to The Sun. The 50-year-old broadcaster began on Working Lunch in 2008, joined BBC Breakfast in 2014 and also hosts a mid-morning slot on Radio 5 Live. She earned £355,000–£359,999 in 2024–25. A PwC HR adviser is assisting with a culture review of the Salford-based programme. Earlier this year, editor Richard Frediani was cleared of similar allegations. Former DG Tim Davie and chair Samir Shah have vowed to address misconduct promptly following an independent workplace review.

articles.title: Is Tim Davie’s successor at the BBC facing the glass cliff? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Judith Flanders describes the glass cliff phenomenon in struggling organisations, while Alan Pearson doubts the BBC has done much to dent Donald Trump’s reputation
articles.summary: Letters: In response to Matthew Ryder’s “silver lining” about having only women candidates to replace Tim Davie, Judith Flanders warns this mirrors the “glass cliff” phenomenon—women are disproportionately appointed to leadership roles in underperforming FTSE 100 firms, raising their odds of failure. Alan Pearson adds that his winter fuel payment would cover any damages if Donald Trump sued the BBC for reputational harm. Readers are invited to submit letters.

articles.title: ‘We’re sick of being the story’: what next for the Telegraph after takeover collapses?
articles.trailText: Media group’s future is again in limbo – and it faces questions over the asking price as well as regulatory hurdles
articles.summary: After RedBird Capital and IMI’s £500m bid to buy the Telegraph collapsed amid newsroom attacks over alleged Chinese links and government scrutiny, the titles face renewed uncertainty. Sellers refuse to lower the price despite flat revenues and profits, even as analysts peg its value closer to £350m. Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy could subject any new offer to Ofcom and CMA review. Potential bidders such as Sir Paul Marshall, Lord Saatchi or Daily Mail’s Lord Rothermere may return when the price is recalibrated. Staff morale is low after two years of deal sagas, and a fresh bidding process is expected.

articles.title: Guardian’s former Gaza correspondent named young journalist of the year in UK awards
articles.trailText: Malak A Tantesh, 20, ‘showed immense talent and bravery’, said judges at Media Freedom awards in London
articles.summary: Malak A Tantesh, 20, the Guardian’s former Gaza correspondent, has been named young journalist of the year in the national press category at the UK Society of Editors’ Media Freedom awards. Judges praised her “immense talent and bravery” reporting for 18 months under bombardment, foraging for food and facing targeted-killing threats. She documented personal loss, her family home’s destruction in Beit Lahia, and a two-year “gateway to hell” of war. She thanked her Gaza-based parents, sister-photographer Enas, cousin Seham and Guardian colleagues. Editor‐in‐chief Katharine Viner hailed her promising future.

articles.title: RedBird Capital drops £500m Telegraph takeover bid
articles.trailText: US private equity group’s deal collapses amid newsroom criticism and threat of regulator intervention
articles.summary: RedBird Capital has withdrawn its £500m bid for Telegraph Media Group after weeks of newsroom criticism over its China ties and potential regulator intervention by Ofcom and the CMA. Against calls from staff and figures like Charles Moore and Fraser Nelson, RedBird cited protracted scrutiny but affirmed confidence in the paper’s future. The deal had envisaged IMI retaining 15% and new stakeholders, including Sir Leonard Blavatnik, each with 10%. Allegations over chair John Thornton’s links to a Chinese spy investigation intensified concerns. TMG’s independent board will now pursue alternative buyers committed to editorial investment.

articles.title: What’s in a name? MS NOW – formerly MSNBC – will soon find out
articles.trailText: On Saturday, after nearly 30 years, the liberal network will officially change its name
articles.summary: After nearly 30 years as MSNBC, the liberal cable network will rebrand on Nov. 16 as MS NOW (“My Source for News, Opinion, and the World”) after NBCUniversal spun it off into a new company, Versant. Network president Rebecca Kutler insists on keeping the legacy “MS,” while hosts like Mika Brzezinski, Joe Scarborough, Rachel Maddow and Jen Psaki back the change. Facing cord-cutting, MS NOW has launched a $20 million national ad campaign with patriotic spots, built an independent DC news bureau after splitting from NBC News, and bets its established stars and digital push on YouTube and TikTok will retain and grow viewership.

articles.title: Are you limiting the time you spend online? We’d like to hear from you
articles.trailText: What prompted this change, and how has it affected you?
articles.summary: Amid frustrations over AI-driven clutter, “enshittification” and polarising feeds, an FT-commissioned GWI study of 250,000 adults in 50+ countries finds social media use peaked in 2022 then dropped nearly 10% to 2 h 20 min daily by late 2024, with youth showing the biggest declines. Readers are invited to describe how and why they’ve cut or deleted accounts, the strategies they use, effects on wellbeing, and how they’re spending regained free time via an online form.

articles.title: Lisa Nandy: BBC review will examine political appointments to board
articles.trailText: Culture secretary says she shares concerns that such appointments have damaged trust, amid calls for Robbie Gibb to go
articles.summary: Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy has confirmed the upcoming BBC charter review will scrutinize political appointments to its board after concerns that figures like Robbie Gibb, ex-Theresa May communications chief, have eroded trust in impartiality. MPs, BBC staff and the Bectu union demand Gibb’s removal as an “untenable distraction” undermining leadership. Amid calls from outgoing DG Tim Davie and leaked allegations of liberal bias by ex-adviser Michael Prescott—citing the Panorama Trump edit—the decade-long review will probe board composition. Both Gibb and Prescott have been summoned by the Commons culture committee. Separately, the BBC apologised to Trump over the spliced clip but refused compensation.

articles.title: BBC apologises to Trump over edited speech but rejects compensation claim
articles.trailText: ‘We strongly disagree there is a basis for a defamation claim’, reads statement expressing ‘sincere regrets’ over Panorama episode
articles.summary: The BBC has apologised to former President Donald Trump for editing and splicing together his January 6, 2021 speech in a Panorama episode—an error revealed by a Michael Prescott internal memo—that led to DG Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness resignations. Chair Samir Shah sent a personal apology and the BBC agreed not to rebroadcast the programme, but its lawyers have rejected Trump’s $1 billion defamation claim and compensation demand, insisting there’s no legal basis. Trump’s next move, potentially filing in Florida, remains uncertain amid questions over libel rules. A BBC spokesperson stressed its high editorial standards and said internal reviews uphold its position.

articles.title: Newsnight accused of selectively editing same Trump Capitol riots speech as Panorama
articles.trailText: BBC show accused of editing speech to make it appear as if Trump made a more explicit call for violence from his supporters
articles.summary: BBC’s Newsnight is accused of splicing Donald Trump’s 6 January 2021 Capitol speech to merge his ‘walk to the Capitol’ comment with a later ‘fight like hell’ exhortation, echoing a Panorama cut that prompted the BBC director-general and head of news to resign. The Telegraph found a 2022 Newsnight edition with the same unflagged edit. Trump has threatened a billion-dollar lawsuit; the BBC says it is investigating after criticism from figures like ex-White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney.

articles.title: Kyle Sandilands rails against ‘pearl-clutchers’ and ‘activist haters’ as regulator reins in radio duo’s antics | The Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Hosts also haunted by mushroom trial comments in dramatic week for Kyle and Jackie O Show. Plus: News Corp reignites fight with ABC
articles.summary: ACMA has moved to impose a five-year additional licence condition on ARN’s Kiis 106.5/101.1 over seven breaches of decency and complaint-handling rules, banning ‘highly offensive’ or explicit sexual content and mandating an independent governance audit. Kyle Sandilands denounces ‘pearl-clutchers’ and ‘activist haters’ and threatens to quit over free-speech concerns. The duo avoided contempt charges after prejudicial trial remarks. The article also covers NYT’s mushroom Wellington gaffe, News Corp reigniting ABC bias claims post-BBC resignations, anti-renewables lobby scrutiny at a climate inquiry, and proposed ‘incentive payments’ for tech platforms bypassing Australia’s news bargaining code.

articles.title: BBC reporter who covered gender dysphoria questions claim of ‘systemic bias’
articles.trailText: Deborah Cohen says she is not aware of any attempts within corporation to stop or shape her reporting on trans issues
articles.summary: Deborah Cohen, BBC reporter on gender dysphoria, refutes claims in a leaked memo by former adviser Michael Prescott that the corporation exhibited systemic pro-trans bias and “effective censorship”. She notes the memo prompted resignations of DG Tim Davie and news boss Deborah Turness, yet BBC ran numerous detailed clinical and evidence-based reports on Newsnight, File on 4, The World at One and Woman’s Hour without internal interference, collaborating with colleagues like Emily Maitlis and Esme Wren.

articles.title: MPs and BBC staff call for Robbie Gibb to leave broadcaster’s board
articles.trailText: Boris Johnson’s appointee is accused of pushing claims of institutional bias at the corporation after shock resignations
articles.summary: BBC board member Robbie Gibb, appointed by Boris Johnson, faces mounting calls from MPs and staff for ouster after he was accused of instigating claims of institutional bias tied to the resignations of director-general Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness. The controversy stems from a leaked memo by ex-adviser Michael Prescott criticizing Panorama’s Trump coverage and alleging liberal bias on trans rights and Gaza. Gibb and Prescott are summoned to testify before the Commons culture committee. Labour, Lib Dem and SNP MPs back removal; Conservatives and the corporation defend the board’s diversity and legal safeguards.

articles.title: The BBC is flawed, but fundamentally truthful | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers react to the resignation of director general Tim Davie, and Donald Trump’s threat to sue the corporation for $1bn
articles.summary: In readers’ letters triggered by DG Tim Davie’s resignation amid bias allegations, former executives call for a leaner, flatter BBC to speed crisis response and cut licence-fee waste. Contributors defend BBC staff’s integrity and argue impartiality requires a purpose-driven agenda of accuracy and public service, warning that attacks by Trump and UK populists risk eroding its truth-telling mission. US readers echo fears of media control loss. Some urge the BBC to countersue Trump’s $1bn fake-news threat, while others see the smear campaign as proof of the corporation’s fundamental honesty.

articles.title: Tim Davie defends BBC against ‘weaponisation’ of criticism
articles.trailText: Outgoing director general tells staff ‘we have to be very clear and stand up for our journalism’
articles.summary: Outgoing BBC director general Tim Davie, following his shock resignation, urged staff to resist the “weaponisation” of political attacks after revelations in a leaked Prescott memo alleged a Panorama edit breaching impartiality. Facing criticism from Boris Johnson, Nigel Farage and Liz Truss, Davie insisted the BBC’s trust and integrity have strengthened and vowed the corporation’s narrative will not be dictated by its detractors. He acknowledged mistakes and took responsibility for his departure, emphasising the need to defend the BBC’s journalism amid pressure over licence fee and alleged internal bias. BBC chair Samir Shah dismissed claims of a rightwing coup on the board as fanciful and stressed healthy diversity of opinion.

articles.title: My wife died but Virgin Media seems unable to transfer account to my name
articles.trailText: Transferring names and moving to a cheaper deal should not require the bereaved to repeatedly explain a death
articles.summary: As he tried to inherit his late wife’s broadband account, a customer faced repeated Virgin Media errors and delays. Over 18 weeks, he was told he must cancel the existing contract and endure a 14-day service blackout or transfer first then wait 30 days before downgrading from £69.21 to £33.99 per month. Multiple calls to bereavement and webchat services forced him to repeatedly explain his wife’s death with no resolution. Virgin Media later acknowledged staff mistakes, apologised and offered the promised lower-cost package. The ordeal exposes callous, inefficient bereavement procedures in telecoms. This ordeal underscores the emotional toll on bereaved customers and corporate incompetence in processing sensitive account changes.

articles.title: BBC board member with Tory links ‘led charge’ in systemic bias claims, say insiders
articles.trailText: Sources say Robbie Gibb amplified criticisms of Trump, Gaza and trans rights coverage, and had ‘a lot of oxygen in the room’
articles.summary: Robbie Gibb, Theresa May’s ex–communications chief and BBC governor appointed under Boris Johnson, spearheaded board pressure over alleged systemic bias in coverage of Trump, Gaza and trans rights, insiders say. His interventions preceded director-general Tim Davie and news head Deborah Turness’s resignations. Liberal Democrat leader Ed Davey urged Gibb’s immediate removal ahead of the DG search. Meanwhile, legal threats from Donald Trump demand retraction of an allegedly misleading Panorama edit and $1bn in damages. Chair Samir Shah apologized for the error but dismissed Michael Prescott’s memo as partial. Critics warn Gibb’s Tory ties and the board’s lack of editorial expertise risk political interference in BBC impartiality.

articles.title: Witnessing the wrath of Richard Gott in Chile | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Neal Ascherson on one of the lowest points in British postwar diplomacy
articles.summary: Neal Ascherson recalls Grace Livingstone’s letter about Richard Gott’s explosive confrontation with the British ambassador in Santiago in the immediate aftermath of Pinochet’s 1973 coup. As death squads hunted dissidents, desperate fugitives scaled foreign embassies, but Britain’s mission alone refused them refuge. The ambassador, elated, celebrated the putsch and the sale of Hawker Hunters to Pinochet’s forces, even the ambassador’s wife lauding the jets overhead. Gott erupted in rage and shame, blasting British policy and leaving the diplomat pale and staff seething, marking a nadir in postwar diplomacy.

articles.title: Who could replace Tim Davie as BBC director general?
articles.trailText: Corporation may seek a candidate with news experience but commercial credentials could also be a prerequisite
articles.summary: Amid bias accusations and ahead of the 2027 charter renewal, BBC chair Samir Shah seeks a successor to Tim Davie with news expertise and commercial acumen. Front-runners include Alex Mahon, former Channel 4 CEO now at Superstruct; Charlotte Moore, ex-BBC content director now at Left Bank; Jay Hunt, Apple TV+ creative chief with 20 years at the BBC; and ITV’s Carolyn McCall. Other possibles: All3Media’s Jane Turton, Sophie Turner Laing, ex-Dow Jones boss Will Lewis and ex-Amazon UK head Doug Gurr.

articles.title: Why the BBC is apologising over a Trump documentary – and what happens next
articles.trailText: Fallout continues over BBC’s editorial standards and claims that exit of bosses is result of ‘campaign by political enemies’
articles.summary: BBC chair Samir Shah apologised for an “error of judgment” after Panorama broadcast a selectively edited Donald Trump speech, prompting the resignations of DG Tim Davie and News CEO Deborah Turness following Michael Prescott’s leaked memo on bias. Backers claim a right-wing campaign targeted the BBC. The board, chaired by Shah with ten non-exec and four exec members, will appoint Davie’s successor. Although ministers have no formal role, government shapes the BBC charter and licence fee. With the charter expiring in 2027, the new DG’s appointment will influence funding, governance and impartiality ahead of renewal negotiations.

articles.title: BBC chair apologises for Trump speech edit but defends corporation against bias claims
articles.trailText: Samir Shah says BBC ‘must champion impartiality’, as Ed Davey warns UK must ‘defend our democracy from foreign interference’
articles.summary: BBC chair Samir Shah apologised to culture committee chair Caroline Dinenage for an “error of judgment” in a Panorama edit that spliced two parts of Donald Trump’s speech—creating the false impression of violent incitement—after ex-adviser Michael Prescott’s leaked memo sparked over 500 complaints. The uproar prompted DG Tim Davie and news head Deborah Turness to resign, though Turness insisted BBC News isn’t institutionally biased. Shah defended the corporation’s impartiality and review process, while ex-Sun editor David Yelland dubbed the shake-up an “internal coup”. Lib Dem leader Ed Davey and No 10 backed the BBC against Trump’s legal threats and Farage’s calls for privatization.

articles.title: BBC in crisis: why did Tim Davie and Deborah Turness resign?
articles.trailText: Director general and head of news quit amid accusations of bias over Trump and trans issues at broadcaster
articles.summary: BBC director-general Tim Davie and news head Deborah Turness resigned after a dossier by ex-adviser Michael Prescott accused the corporation of impartiality breaches—including selectively editing Donald Trump’s January 6 speech for Panorama, alleged anti-Israel bias in BBC Arabic, and a narrow ‘Stonewall’ line on trans issues. Chair Samir Shah is set to apologise. Senior Conservatives and Trump’s press secretary attacked the BBC. Presenters Nick Robinson and John Simpson acknowledged errors amid what they called a partisan campaign.

articles.title: Will Tim Davie’s resignation be enough to restore public trust in the BBC?
articles.trailText: Senior insiders admit concern about big editorial errors and fear attacks are part of ongoing campaign to undermine the broadcaster
articles.summary: In early November 2025, director-general Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness resigned after a leaked report by former adviser Michael Prescott alleged Panorama misedited a Donald Trump speech, triggering right-wing criticism and internal alarm over ‘serious and systemic’ bias. Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy and senior BBC staff privately warn of politically motivated campaigns undermining the broadcaster. Facing a 2027 charter review, government insiders seek reforms to secure editorial independence while boosting accountability. Restoring public trust now depends on fair, accurate reporting free from ideological bias.

articles.title: ‘I have to take ultimate responsibility’: Tim Davie’s BBC resignation statement
articles.trailText: Full text of director general’s note to staff and the resignation statement from head of news Deborah Turness
articles.summary: BBC Director-General Tim Davie and News CEO Deborah Turness have resigned amid accusations of “serious and systemic” bias in the corporation’s coverage of Donald Trump, Gaza and trans rights. After 20 years, Davie said he would step down to allow a successor to shape the next Royal Charter, thanked the board, staff and global audiences, and took “ultimate responsibility” for recent mistakes. Turness, who led BBC News since 2022, also offered her resignation over the Panorama–Trump controversy, defended the impartiality of BBC journalism, praised her team’s work and pledged an orderly handover.

articles.title: Tim Davie resigns as BBC director general after accusations of ‘serious and systemic’ bias in coverage
articles.trailText: Davie says departure is ‘my own decision’, while head of news also quits. Insiders say it ‘feels like a coup’ by broadcaster’s enemies
articles.summary: BBC director-general Tim Davie and head of News Deborah Turness resigned after ex-adviser Michael Prescott accused the corporation of “serious and systemic” bias in coverage of Trump, Gaza and trans rights. Their departures come as the BBC prepares to apologise for splicing Donald Trump’s January 6 speech on Panorama, despite board support from chairman Samir Shah. Critics from Trump’s press secretary Karoline Leavitt to UK politicians Nigel Farage, Ed Davey and Kemi Badenoch demand top-to-bottom reform. Prescott’s letter also highlighted antisemitic contributors on BBC Arabic amid wider debates over impartiality and funding.

articles.title: Tim Davie: the marketing man who became the BBC’s director general
articles.trailText: The media boss navigated the corporation through years of crisis and controversy
articles.summary: Tim Davie, a former PepsiCo marketing executive, joined the BBC in 2005 to lead marketing and later its audio and music division, where he controversially proposed closing 6 Music and the Asian Network and managed the Russell Brand prank fallout. After stints as BBC Worldwide chief and acting director-general during the Savile/McAlpine crises, he merged Worldwide into BBC Studios in 2018. Appointed director-general in 2020, Davie has since navigated high-profile controversies—from Gary Lineker’s 2023 suspension to Ofcom sanctions over Gaza coverage—while overseeing governance roles and earning a CBE in 2018.

articles.title: BBC bias row: how a week of hostile headlines from rightwing media led to resignations
articles.trailText: Rightwing media have published a series of attacks on the corporation after a memo from a former BBC adviser critical of its output
articles.summary: Rightwing outlets led by The Telegraph launched a week-long campaign over a leaked memo by ex-advisor Michael Prescott alleging BBC editorial bias—accusing Panorama of doctoring Trump’s speech, minimizing Israeli suffering and censoring transgender reporting. Successive front pages from Daily Telegraph, Daily Mail and Sunday titles demanded Tim Davie’s ousting as Tory figures (Kemi Badenoch, Lord Grade) and Boris Johnson amplified claims, and White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt branded the corporation "100% fake news." Culture secretary Lisa Nandy vowed scrutiny, but Davie and BBC News head Deborah Turness resigned under mounting pressure.

articles.title: Lisa Nandy says she still has confidence in BBC leaders after Trump speech edit
articles.trailText: Culture secretary has spoken to BBC chair Samir Shah about criticised edit of US president’s 6 January 2021 speech
articles.summary: Culture secretary Lisa Nandy affirmed her confidence in BBC chair Samir Shah and director-general Tim Davie after Panorama spliced clips from Donald Trump’s January 6, 2021 speech to imply he told supporters 'we fight like hell,' prompting a forthcoming apology. The edit, revealed alongside a letter by former external adviser Michael Prescott accusing the BBC of systemic bias on Gaza, trans rights and antisemitism in BBC Arabic, has drawn criticism from Trump’s press secretary and scrutiny by the Commons culture, media and sport select committee. Nandy, who has discussed the matter with Shah, warned that blurred lines between fact and opinion threaten public trust.

articles.title: John Laws, Australian radio’s ‘Golden Tonsils’ who dominated airwaves for six decades – obituary
articles.trailText: Unapologetically provocative broadcaster’s ability to connect with his audience significantly influenced talkback radio
articles.summary: John Laws, dubbed the “Golden Tonsils”, died aged 90, leaving a six-decade legacy as Australia’s highest-paid talkback broadcaster. From his 1953 debut in regional Victoria to primetime slots on 2UE, 2GB and 2SM, his rich voice and candid style drove record ratings and turned advertisers into loyal sponsors. He influenced politicians, faced the 1999 cash-for-comment scandal, contempt and decency breaches, yet retained a devoted audience. Married to Caroline Cameron Waller for 43 years, Laws overcame polio, battled depression and penned poetry, songs and cookbooks. Inducted into the Radio Hall of Fame, he shaped modern talk radio.

articles.title: Some investors in AI ‘are extremely autocratic’, says ABC chair Kim Williams
articles.trailText: Exclusive: While fearing the technology can be an ‘employment destroyer’ in other industries, Williams believes it won’t be as damaging for the media
articles.summary: ABC chair Kim Williams, an active user of ChatGPT, Gemini and Perplexity, warns that AI can embed the ‘extremely autocratic’ views of its funders, producing ‘dangerous and sinister’ outcomes. He urges disciplined understanding of AI’s social power, cautions against censorship or concentration of control, and highlights real-world risks in government hands. Williams stresses media partnerships with AI firms must serve public and national interest, defends creators’ rights against copyright exemptions, foresees entry-level job losses in law and accounting, but predicts journalism will adapt and benefit from AI tools.

articles.title: BBC ‘100% fake news’, says Donald Trump’s press secretary
articles.trailText: Comments by Karoline Leavitt follow allegations that Panorama documentary misled viewers with its editing of a Trump speech
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s press secretary Karoline Leavitt blasted the BBC as “100% fake news” and a “leftist propaganda machine” after MPs raised concerns over a leaked memo alleging Panorama editors misled viewers by splicing Trump’s January 6 speech—omitting his call for peaceful protest—and prompting a potential BBC apology to the Culture, Media and Sport Committee. The 19-page dossier by former BBC adviser Michael Prescott also criticizes coverage of Gaza on BBC Arabic and transgender issues, accusing the broadcaster of one-sided reporting, a charge the BBC says it reviews seriously.

articles.title: The Tube presenter, the former ballerina and the banker: the BBC board’s members
articles.trailText: While the director general, Tim Davie, is often in the spotlight, here is what you need to know about the rest of the broadcaster’s leadership
articles.summary: BBC board (2025–29) is led by chair Samir Shah (ex-Juniper CEO, former BBC current affairs head, co-author of the 2021 UK racism report); deputy chair Sir Damon Buffini (ex-Permira, Cultural Recovery Fund chair); director general Tim Davie (BBC Studios chief, ex-PepsiCo, suspended Gary Lineker); news and current affairs CEO Deborah Turness (ex-ITN/NBC); COO Leigh Tavaziva (former British Gas MD, ex-ballerina); senior independent director Caroline Thomson (ex-Oxfam, arts executive); regional members Robbie Gibb, Muriel Gray, Michael Plaut, Michael Smyth; and non-executives Shumeet Banerji, Chris Jones, Marinella Soldi.

articles.title: Michael Kenward obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Editor of New Scientist who transformed it into a truly popular magazine
articles.summary: Michael Kenward, who died aged 80, edited New Scientist from 1979 to 1990, transforming it from a specialist “house journal” into a popular science magazine with accessible writing, striking design and illustrated covers, boosting circulation and winning a 1987 BSME prize. He helped embed the public understanding of science, campaigned for British science under Thatcher and co-founded COPUS in 1985. Born in Brighton in 1945, educated at Sussex, he joined New Scientist in 1969, earned an OBE in 1990 and later freelanced for outlets including the Sunday Times and Ingenia. He lived in Staplefield with wife Liz; she and brother Malcolm survive him.

articles.title: What is Roblox and should parents be worried about whether it’s safe for children?
articles.trailText: The ability for kids and adults to chat and interact has led to reports of minors being groomed for abuse while playing online
articles.summary: Roblox is a global platform of user-created games with built-in chat on multiple devices. It’s the No.2 game among Australian under-16s, prompting calls to include it in the forthcoming social-media ban. Authorities warn of grooming for abuse and extremism, with reports of sexual harassment and Nazi/IS-themed games. Exempted because gaming is its primary purpose, but the dynamic ban list could expand. eSafety commissioner Julie Inman Grant led negotiations on safety. Roblox will roll out by year-end age assurance: under-16 accounts default to private, chat and voice off until age-verified, and adults cannot contact minors without parental consent.

articles.title: Angry shareholders vote against SevenWest executive pay deal as Kerry Stokes says he too has suffered | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: The media tycoon presided over his presumptive last annual general meeting as Seven West Media’s chair. Plus: ABC’s 90s hit returns, but will it work?
articles.summary: At Seven West Media’s AGM, outgoing chair Kerry Stokes—presiding over his last meeting amid an impending merger—told shareholders executives received no bonuses this year, but ignored calls for dividends as shares have fallen 30%, triggering a “first strike” vote against the executive pay plan. Elsewhere, Tom Switzer returned to The Australian after leaving the CIS amid harassment claims; ABC is reviving 1990s docuseries Race Around the World in 2026; Maitland council will distribute free Australian flags for Australia Day; and the disappearance of South Australian boy Gus Lamont draws fresh controversy after his grandmother aimed a shotgun at a Daily Mail reporter.

articles.title: Richard Gott was a groundbreaking, schmooz-proof journalist | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Grace Livingstone and Martin Hamilton reflect on the work and interests of the late writer and historian
articles.summary: Grace Livingstone and Martin Hamilton pay tribute to Richard Gott, whose 1970s reporting from Chile and Argentina exposed dictatorship atrocities. He resisted pro-Pinochet influence by the British embassy’s IRD, broke the story of the ‘disappeared’ in Argentina, and was lauded by the Foreign Office as a leading Latin America correspondent. In 2018 he humorously unveiled a plaque to ancestor Benjamin Gott, whose textiles once clad opposing armies.

articles.title: BBC upholds complaint against Martine Croxall over ‘pregnant people’ change
articles.trailText: Newsreader’s raised eyebrows as she switched to ‘women’ suggested a viewpoint on trans identity, corporation says
articles.summary: BBC’s executive complaints unit upheld 20 complaints after newsreader Martine Croxall replaced “pregnant people” with “women” and raised her eyebrows during a summer broadcast on heatwave risk, based on an LSHTM study, prompting viewers to read a personal stance on trans identity. Under impartiality rules presenters must avoid controversial views; Croxall and her editorial team were reprimanded. The incident, which trended online and drew praise from JK Rowling, was judged to convey exasperation at the scripted phrase, reinforcing interpretations across the debate. Croxall later thanked new followers on X.

articles.title: From AusLegal to AmItheAsshole: why I’m downvoting the social media ban on Reddit | Deirdre Fidge
articles.trailText: We know young people are dancing on Tik Tok, and doing whatever the hell is happening on Kick, but my sympathies are with those about to be booted off Reddit
articles.summary: Deirdre Fidge criticises Australia’s upcoming ban requiring under-16s off Reddit, joining Facebook, Instagram, X, Snapchat and new platform Kick. She argues that Reddit’s text-based subreddits—from r/thallasophobia to AITA, AusLegal and queer support groups—offer vital community, advice and safety nets for young, niche-interests and vulnerable teens. While acknowledging online harms, Fidge warns the prohibition may drive teens to illicit workarounds or deprive them of peer support, trading crates of cockroach fantasies for essential solidarity. She compares Reddit to niches for bullied kids, contrasts it with image-driven Instagram or boomer-filled Facebook, and highlights insomnia-driven late-night browsing. Invoking US prohibition, Fidge predicts teens will circumvent the ban via older siblings’ phones, false birthdates or black-market apps, questioning whether outlawing Reddit will spur more harm than protect them.

articles.title: CNN’s All Access election night ‘watch party’ might not be the network’s future
articles.trailText: Its subscriber-only election special, aiming to make politics fun and fresh, instead felt offbeat and out of touch
articles.summary: CNN’s new $6.99/month All Access service debuted an exclusive election-night “watch party” hosted by Harry Enten with panelists Ben Shapiro, Charlamagne tha God, Ana Kasparian and Isabel Brown. Designed as a casual set with couches and games, the two-hour livestream offered few real-time returns—viewers learned of Zohran Mamdani’s NYC mayor victory only after a side note—and panel discussions often felt ideologically narrow and disconnected from live results. Enten’s final push to end the show on a debate about Mamdani’s character underscored the offbeat, out-of-touch format, raising doubts about similar future exclusives.

articles.title: BBC must change or be ‘a Titanic’, says manager of the Sidemen YouTubers
articles.trailText: Jordan Schwarzenberger says BBC is becoming irrelevant to gen Z and risks crashing unless it attracts younger viewers
articles.summary: Jordan Schwarzenberger, manager of YouTube collective the Sidemen (100m+ subscribers), warns the BBC risks becoming “a Titanic” if it fails a radical shift to Gen Z, who largely avoid traditional broadcasting and demand TikTok-style formats. He highlights a seismic pre-TikTok/post-TikTok split in viewing habits and accuses BBC executives of a “defeatist mentality” and disconnect from youth attention patterns. He urges investing in emerging creators and adapting content distribution. The BBC cites expanding Instagram, TikTok and YouTube presence and its UNBOXD youth research project.

articles.title: Reddit added to Australia’s under-16s social media ban as ‘dynamic’ list of online services grows
articles.trailText: Popular platform added to list of companies required to restrict access for children, along with video streaming site Kick
articles.summary: Following legislation effective 10 Dec, Australia’s eSafety commissioner has added Reddit and livestream platform Kick to a “dynamic list” of services banned to under-16s, joining Facebook, Snapchat, Instagram, X, YouTube and TikTok. Companies must self-assess inclusion or face fines up to AU$49.5m. Commissioner Julie Inman Grant warns other services—Discord, Roblox, Steam, OpenAI’s Sora, Bluesky and Twitch—may be added. Communications minister Anika Wells and shadow minister Melissa McIntosh flagged risks of “policy on the run” and user workarounds. TikTok, Snapchat, Meta will comply; YouTube and X dissent.

articles.title: Tell us: what 90s dance track would you gift to your teenager?
articles.trailText: The John Lewis Christmas ad boy buys his dad a vinyl copy of the house track Where Love Lives by Alison Limerick. But what would be your choice?
articles.summary: In its 2025 Christmas advert, John Lewis features a boy gifting his father a vinyl of Alison Limerick’s 1990 house hit “Where Love Lives.” Noting that music lovers might choose different anthems, the Guardian invites readers to nominate the 90s club track they’d gift to a teenager in their family, sharing personal stories and photos. The community callout closed on 5 November 2025, with respondents’ picks published in a follow-up article. Readers can still join future calls via the Community callouts or Share a story pages.

articles.title: BBC’s Kingdom series gets viewers ‘into the action’ with TV drama techniques
articles.trailText: New David Attenborough show’s use of drones and moving cameras creates immersive experience like Adolescence
articles.summary: BBC’s six-part natural history series Kingdom follows four predator families—lions, leopards, wild dogs and hyenas—around a Zambian river, documenting their ecological interplay when wild dogs encroach. Producers deploy small, quiet 'flying cinematographer' drones and vehicle-mounted moving cameras to capture continuous, intimate footage, mimicking drama conventions like cliffhangers and dynamic shots popularised by shows such as Netflix’s Adolescence. Innovations include light-sensitive rigs for longer shoots, a solar-powered base camp, and five years of on-site filming. Executive producer Mike Gunton and series producer Felicity Lanchester tout a new "gold standard" in immersive wildlife storytelling, underpinned by David Attenborough’s reassuring narration.

articles.title: John Lewis ad kickstarts Christmas countdown to the tune of 90s club classic
articles.trailText: Department store chain banks on nostalgia to get customers into festive mood with Where Love Lives
articles.summary: John Lewis has launched its 2025 Christmas advert – 10 days earlier than last year – to the 1990s club hit “Where Love Lives” by Alison Limerick, remixed by Labrinth. Created by Saatchi & Saatchi, the spot follows a middle-aged dad who rediscovers his youth after his son gifts him a vinyl record, underlining family bonds over cute characters. A limited edition £14.99 vinyl, sold via Rough Trade sections and its app, supports the Partnership’s Building Happier Futures programme. The campaign debuts to loyalty members, on YouTube and during The Great British Bake Off finale as retailers vie for early festive spend amid rising ad budgets.

articles.title: David Gow, former Guardian Germany correspondent, dies aged 80
articles.trailText: ‘Impressively professional journalist’ with a commitment to social justice was also European business editor
articles.summary: David Gow, 80, a former Guardian Germany correspondent and European business editor, has died of a heart attack. An Oxford‐educated linguist fluent in French and German, he began at the Scotsman in 1969 and covered German reunification in Bonn before returning to London and then Brussels as business correspondent until retiring in 2012. A lifelong pro-EU campaigner and social justice advocate, he contributed to Social Europe, the Jacques Delors Centre and EMiS, served on the NUJ executive, and was elected a Royal Society of Edinburgh fellow in 2023. He is survived by his wife Gayle, daughter Gemma, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

articles.title: BBC accused of selectively editing Trump clip from day of Capitol attack
articles.trailText: Panorama spliced together clips to make it appear clearer president encouraged attack, former external adviser says
articles.summary: Former BBC adviser Michael Prescott accused Panorama of splicing two January 6, 2021 Trump speech segments—nearly an hour apart—to imply he urged supporters to walk to the Capitol and fight "like hell," omitting his call for peaceful protest. Prescott's dossier flagged misleading footage and pre-speech march clips, claiming he circulated it in despair at BBC inaction. The BBC says it reviews all feedback. The dispute risks further straining BBC-White House relations after past accusations.

articles.title: Telegraph bidder reported for potential breach of editorial independence rules
articles.trailText: UK government alerted after RedBird Capital’s boss allegedly threatened to ‘go to war’ with the title’s newsroom
articles.summary: RedBird Capital CEO Gerry Cardinale, bidder for the Daily Telegraph, has been reported to the DCMS by independent TMG directors for allegedly threatening to “go to war” with the newsroom and replace editor Chris Evans—potentially breaching 2024 statutory editorial-independence rules that protect key staff and require government notification. The sale, after the Barclays ceded control to RedBird IMI (backed by Abu Dhabi’s IMI), was revived when a 2025 law permitted up to 15% foreign stakes. RedBird pledges an independent advisory board under Lord Black to safeguard journalistic integrity.

articles.title: David Gow obituary
articles.trailText: Journalist, gifted linguist and European business editor of the Guardian who was dismayed by Brexit
articles.summary: Guardian journalist David Gow (1945–2025) served as education editor, Germany correspondent and European business editor, covering the Cold War’s end, 9/11 and EU affairs. A graduate of Oxford in French and German, his fluency and Europhile convictions made him a leading commentator who decried Brexit. Beginning at the Scotsman and Thames TV, he later reported from Brussels and Wall Street. Post-retirement he advised EU think tanks, co-founded the Sceptical Scot forum and blogged on community issues. He is survived by wife Gayle, daughter Gemma, three grandchildren, three great-grandchildren and brother Rod.

articles.title: TalkTV breached impartiality rules with allegations about cancelled local elections, Ofcom finds
articles.trailText: Claim that elections were cancelled because ministers were ‘terrified of Reform’ given rare rebuke by regulator
articles.summary: Ofcom finds TalkTV breached due impartiality rules after host Kevin O’Sullivan and Isabel Oakeshott repeatedly claimed ministers cancelled 13 local elections out of fear of Reform UK’s Nigel Farage, describing government warnings on boundary changes as “old drivel.” The rare regulatory ruling criticized absence of the government viewpoint. Ministers had explained postponements as cost-saving amid local authority reorganizations. News UK acknowledged the lapse, noting Talk’s provocative tone. Launched in 2022 and online-only since 2024, TalkTV trails GB News in growth.

articles.title: Richard Gott obituary
articles.trailText: Journalist, historian and author who served as a foreign correspondent and features editor of the Guardian
articles.summary: Richard Gott, 87, Guardian journalist and historian, witnessed the CIA-monitored display of Che Guevara’s body in Bolivia in 1967. A leader writer on European affairs and features editor (1978–89) then literary editor (1992–94), he authored seminal works on Latin America including Cuba: A New History (2004), Guerrilla Movements in Latin America (1970) and Britain’s Empire (2011). His career suffered a blow in 1994 when he admitted accepting Soviet-paid trips and expenses. Married twice, father of two, he remained a passionate critic of imperialism and settler colonialism, survived by second wife Vivien, children Inti and Araucana and six grandchildren.

articles.title: Richard Gott, former Guardian journalist and historian, dies aged 87
articles.trailText: Charismatic figure of the left is remembered as one of the most informed commentators on Latin American affairs
articles.summary: Richard Gott, who died aged 87, was a Guardian journalist from 1964 to 1994 and later contributor, serving as foreign correspondent, leader writer, features and literary editor. A leading expert on Latin America, he met Che Guevara in 1963 and identified his body in Bolivia in 1967. In 1994 he resigned amid KGB informer allegations which he denied though he admitted accepting Soviet-funded trips. He launched the Guardian’s influential Agenda page, stood for the Radical Alliance in 1966, and authored acclaimed works on appeasement and Cuba. He co-authored the bestselling 'The Appeasers' early in his career and in 2004 published the authoritative 'Cuba: A New History'.

articles.title: Who will Bari Weiss pick as the next anchor of CBS Evening News?
articles.trailText: With John Dickerson heading out and show’s ratings struggling, new CBS editor-in-chief is looking at several anchors at rival networks
articles.summary: Bari Weiss, CBS News’s new editor-in-chief, must replace departing co-anchor John Dickerson and revive the struggling CBS Evening News. Management, including president Tom Cibrowski, will likely shift back to a single-anchor format, weighing internal candidates like Tony Dokoupil or Norah O’Donnell against external anchors Bret Baier, Anderson Cooper and Dana Perino—all tied to multi-year contracts—and the unlikely Shepard Smith. A January revamp favoring in-depth reports over Washington briefs failed to boost viewership, leaving CBS third (3.7 M) behind ABC’s 7.5 M and NBC’s 5.7 M. Weiss’s choice will signal her broader turnaround strategy.

articles.title: ABC executive who sacked Antoinette Lattouf paid $836,000 for eight-month employment, annual report shows
articles.trailText: Chris Oliver-Taylor’s remuneration exceeded by former managing director David Anderson’s $1.2m package, broadcaster says
articles.summary: ABC’s annual report shows ex-chief content officer Chris Oliver-Taylor earned $836,098 over eight months including a $342,436 payout after his role was downgraded weeks before he was due to testify in Antoinette Lattouf’s legal case. A federal court found he unlawfully terminated Lattouf over her Gaza views, costing the broadcaster $2.5m in defense. Chair Kim Williams and new MD Hugh Marks apologized. Top executive pay included former MD David Anderson on $1.2m. ABC’s funding fell 13.7% in real terms, wages rose to $619m, contractor costs hit $48m, 50 roles cut, and iview users rose to 2.4m weekly.

articles.title: News Corp books in advertisers in campaign for a ‘self-reliant’ Australia that ‘made things here’ | Weekly Beast
articles.trailText: Daily Telegraph editor says the campaign aligns with the values of its backers, which include RM Williams, Qantas and Bunnings. Plus: Stokes defiant on BRS
articles.summary: News Corp has rolled out a sales-driven “Back Australia” campaign—fronted by Daily Telegraph columnist Joe Hildebrand and supported by brands from RM Williams to Bunnings—urging a return to 1960s manufacturing and national self-reliance, despite its own outlets’ past free-market critiques. Elsewhere, the ABC ombudsman dismissed 108 identical complaints accusing its Gaza coverage of bias; Ita Buttrose’s new memoir notably omits her role in the Lattouf dismissal dispute; and Seven West’s Kerry Stokes, amid a $13.5 m defamation cost order, defends funding Ben Roberts-Smith and insists on newsroom editorial independence.

articles.title: Jean Finlayson obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Campaigning journalist who wrote for the Guardian and the Times
articles.summary: Jean Finlayson, US-born journalist and campaigner, died aged 91. Raised in rural Illinois, she won a journalism scholarship at the University of Missouri (1956) and worked on a farming magazine while piloting herself across Texas. After moving to the UK in 1958, she joined CND protests, married Scottish biochemist Vic Finlayson in 1963, and freelanced for the Guardian, Times and Sunday Times. She raised awareness of dyslexia, child custody ‘tug of love’ cases and domestic violence. From 1970–77 she columned for the Bath Evening Chronicle and then edited publications at the Further Education Staff College until 1989. An avid traveller and reader, she faced dementia in later years. Survived by two children and four grandchildren.

articles.title: WPP jobs at risk as ad group’s new boss condemns ‘unacceptable’ performance
articles.trailText: Review launched after firm struggles to stem exodus of clients and compete with AI and data capabilities of rivals
articles.summary: WPP’s new CEO Cindy Rose has launched a strategic review after a fresh profit warning, citing “unacceptable” performance as client losses mount and rivals outpace the ad group in AI and data capabilities.
